A STELLAR EVENT. Classical ballet & Russia go together, what better place to enjoy it than at the Mariinsky. Bought our tickets ( Belle -Etage ) directly from www.mariinsky.ru & tickets are available from around four weeks before the performance. Worth bringing some smart clothes as the Russian are well dressed - Russian champagne not bad a third of the cost of French. Arrive early & enjoy a drink & a wonder around the exhibits. We saw Don Quixote which was excellent even though the under study had to take over in the last act for the main male dancer. Arrived by taxi,but decided to walk back to our hotel as it was chaos outside - should have organized the return in advance.

The Fountain of Bakhchisarai. It was a wonderful experience and a great performance. It was nice to see that most of the people were Russians and so nicely dressed, we could learn here in the West, that for every ocassion one should dress. But beware as a tourist one pays more than the locals.

Old Marinsky does not disappoint. We lucked out and had opening night tickets to the famous Kirov Ballet, "Les Sylphides" at the Old Marinsky. We were front and centre up on the fist tier. Simply great ballet and theatre. Boys was the champagne was Russian, reasonably priced and not bad to drink! Also had salmon open sandwiches and strawberries and cream! Don't miss out on the ultimate cultural experience.

magic dream. Mariinka old building looks what an Opers House should look like: grand main hall and narrow corridors. The main hall is really majestic in traditional for this theatre blue and gold colours, with magnificent boxes and a luxury curtain. I was lucky to watch ballet "Midsummer Night's Dream from the 1st row of stalls. Not a detail of the show or orchestra pit was left out. Tremendous dancers, the glory of Russian ballet school! Not to be missed when in St Petersburg!

Stunning theatre (but choose seats carefully). Saw an opera which was great and I am not an opera fan. Sets were fantastic, sound excellent, atmosphere great, inside the building was stunning. Had seats in the front row first gallery circle which were great. Do not get the seat next to the tsars box in the first gallery circle or you will be staring partially at a gold part of the Tsars box. Also here the second row is on the same level as the front row and there is virtually no leg room, I strongly advise not to get second row seats. Third row is in fact better as it is raised. Having run around the other galleries most of the front row seats seem fine but of course the angle is steeper and very steep at the 3rd gallery. Cloakroom, food, drinks all available . English insert in programme was available for the event I attended. No photos during performance but no problem before or after.
Must Go.... I visited the theatre for "Swan Lake"..magnificent. If one have a change must see. Excellent, mesmerizing, unforgettable

What a place to go to the ballet!. The Miriinsky is in its 231st season! We saw the Kirov ballet perform Mid Summers night dream. It was beautiful and the first ballet I have seen with a choir. There are five levels of boxes. The seats are tiny. If I went again I would sit on the main floor because the guy in front of me was big and didn't want to be there and leaned forward blocking 1/3 of the stage. You can buy your tickets on line and choose your own seats. There are 3 Mariinsky theaters , this one Mariinsky 2 and a one year old concert hall.
As good as we imagined. We had seats next to the Royal box which were amazing. The acoustics were fantastic and the dancing sublime. A must visit for all to this city

New stage is great. I've been to the old theatre and the new stage and both are incredible. The acoustics in the new theatre are astounding and the seating is arranged such that everyone has a good view. Went to see Madam Butterfly which was only average but the experience was fantastic.

A night at the Ballet. We had a wonderful evening. Prime seats, front row in the balcony but it was very, very warm in the theatre. we were dressed black tie while most others only bothered with 'smart casual' attire. Difficult to get a drink at interval - even then they were overpriced. Opted to hire 'glasses' which meant we beat the queue when we returned for our coats after the performance. Theatre has such a wonderful history making for a great evening.
Majestic theatre. Stunning interior which must have a lot of stories to tell. We saw the fantastic classical ballet "Mid summer nights dream"

We loved every minute.. We booked directly on the theatre's website thanks to the advice and help on TA.It was a week night and I was amazed at the number of Russian children there. We did go to see The Firebird however I thought the children might go to a matinee.Although the performance was sold out, there appeared to be empty seats and just as the lights when down, the locals were jostling for better seats towards the front.Although there was a bilingual announcement saying no cameras allowed during the performance, that was pretty much ignored.

Historic opera in the right setting. Peter is oozing culture in all areas; writers, composers, balletdancers, etc etc So naturally you need to go and take advance and enjoy a concert, see a show or an opera. Buy ticketts on the internet for Mariinsky 1 and you are all set. Front row ticket is a great buy, but any seat is nice in order to experience this historic place. Make sure that you get tickets to the old part of the Theater. The new part is impressive but not significant for the city

The New Theater: A Contemporary Classic. I was lucky to see both Don Quixote in Mariinsky-1 and Jewels in Mariinsky-2 during my mid-May visit to St. Petersburg. The company was in fabulous form and both productions were stunning. It was my first return to the original theater in 14 years and nothing much had appeared to have changed. The new theater is striking and its streamlined warm wooden interiors are a lovely complement to the over the top drama of the original theater. Travelers to St. Petersburg should not miss an opportunity to attend performances at the Mariinsky, especially the ballet if it is performing. The Mariinsky web site is easy to navigate and I had no problems using my e-tickets.

Miss the Mozart. We had to go (well you do don't you)! We didn't regret the experience for a second but Covent Garden it ain't. The singers gave it their all but the director should have been shot. Regrettably most of the audience seem to be there to sneakily take photographs of the production through their iphones throughout the entire performance!!!! Maybe they could try listening to the music instead? Fat chance!!

Cultural lodestone. One of the most important theatres in the world, at least judged by who has performed in it and what it has done for ballet globally. We got a great piece of advice from Tripadvisor which I am going to repeat here, which is that if you buy seats in the First Circle, go for the front row or the third (a few boxes towards the middle have a raised area at the back for this), but avoid the second row because you won't see so well. The Russian sparkling wine was great, and at 200 roubles a glass a much better bet than 5,000 for a bottle of NV Moet et Chandon.Anyway, the sight lines were fine and the theatre is a stunner to sit in. Compared to what I expected after reading other reviews, dress wasn't too overwhelming - smart casual really will be fine and you'll fit in. At least, you'd have fitted in on our Wednesday night performance of Don Quixote. Dancing was of course astonishing. About £40 each for very good tickets. You won't get better value in London or New York.

Memorable evening at Ballet. We visited the theatre without a great appreciation of ballet but were awe struck at the music,dance and settings. The theatre itself exuded atmosphere and history. The visit was a night to remember and was worth every cent of the admission fee which was quite expensive.

Majestic and Magical. No trip to Saint Petersburg is complete without experiencing the ballet at the Mariinsky Theatre. The old theatre itself is magnificent; the famed ballet company is beyond spectacular. However, dress up for this! The Russian people take their ballet seriously and, especially the women, will be dressed to the nines. I did not go to the new Mariinsky Theatre, a modern structure just behind the old one, but it looks impressive, too, albeit in a wholly different way.

Fabulous Rasulka. This was in the new theatre, which was very smart and classy. We had to rush there after a busy day, no time to change. Nit did not matter, but there were some beautifully dressed locals. Excellent pre opera refreshments of smoked salmon and Prosecco. You could also get these at the intervals. Sur titles were in English - very helpful. Staging was modern, and sea nymph and wraith costumes were fabulous.

Old world elegance!. If you are a bit interested in culture, the old Marinskii is a must see during any trip to St. Petersburg. I went last September with my father to see the Masquerade. Unforgettable experience in an amazing theatre.

Cheap for students and beautiful. Although tickets to the bigger shows are very expensive (Swan Lake, the Nutcracker) you can get some very well priced tickets to the Mariinsky, and if it's within your budget, it's well worth going. An unbelievably stunning theatre with chandeliers and of course covered in the typical Baroque gold, it puts on only the highest quality shows.

A magical evening. The Russian ballet is always of a very high quality, and the three classic Russian ballets we saw were superb. We booked our tickets through www.balletandopera.com and they were waiting for us at our hotel. We even got an upgrade! The people watching opportunities were fascinating, and I was delighted to see that everybody dresses up. We liked being able to leave our coats and walking shoes at the cloakroom for no extra charge, and there was plenty of room to sit down and enjoy our drink at the interval.

Exceeded expectations. I had expected the visit to see the Mariinsky (Kirov) ballet to be inspiring but found the whole evening extremely moving and very beautiful. This is not a cheap night out but is worth every rouble!

Wonderful ballet. We really enjoyed the performance but were rather disappointed with the decor inside the venue which was not as ornate as outside. If you go on a cold day you are forced to queue to leave your coat and are not allowed inside with it so leave lots of time. Order drinks for the interval and they serve food too if you require it.
Classic!. A beautiful old classic theatre with a great atmosphere. A little off the beaten track - but very much worth the search.

all the world's a stage. as theatres go this one is impressive, as theatres go this one is not cheap.. is it good? a lot depends on what you go to see. Russia is famous for its ballets but even at Mikhailovsky theatre in SPB you can get excellent ballet shows for a cheaper price . I prefer going to the Russian Operas ( you get subtitles in English) as some of the Russians singing the Italian parts can be a surprising disappointment. Dress well - Russians dress up and you will definitely feel underdressed if you are not up to scratch. If taking children check the age limit before buying tickets as it varies for each show. If you love theatre this is a must even if just to sit and enjoy the grandeur, but do your homework well in choosing - not all shows are great - read the reviews.

Beautiful. We were lucky to get a present of two tickets for the opera here. It is a beautiful theatre and the opera Sadco was great. In the second half there was a lot of ballet and it was a joy to behold. There are lots of events on here so try and get to see a ballet or opera as it was a highlight of our visit. It was lovely to sit and have champagne during the interval at a reasonable cost

Must visit place. My best experience for the whole 2 week trip. The room was grand and awesome! 1st time in my life i have seen such a grand classic concert hall, never regret buying a pair of tickets to watch the ballet. It is world class! Tips: every one is well dress, we felt under dress when we are there.the transport can get quite messy when the performance end, we could not find the return bus stop and had to walk our way back. Do check the return route before going, it may not be the same way as how you came.

A magical night out. We went to the Mariinsky II to see Il Travatore. The Theatre is breathtaking with the foyer alone featuring beige marble and Swarovski crystal lights, with backlit walls of translucent onyx. The staging is amazing with clearly back stage capacity that exceeds most. Do yourself a favour at interval and have a glass of champagne and a chocolate éclair or a salmon baguette. Otherwise just wander around and enjoy the space and the displays of costumes and sets. Great sound, fantastic opera company and loads of fun. You can rent binoculars at the well organised cloak room. Get tickets at their box office, on the top floor of the fabulous Gostiny Dvor shopping centre on Nevsky Prospect of course - and then ticket prices are reasonable.

Mariinsky Theatre 1 - beautiful. We saw Mussorgsky's Khovanschina and it was epic! I was not a fan of opera, though hubby is and I felt it was only fair that I agree to go to one of the best places in the world to see it. I am so pleased I did. Incredible performances and the music was absolutely amazing. The building itself is beautiful inside and out, with grand halls and quaint corners all with imperial style decor. We were very lucky to get extremely reasonable tickets just above the Tsars box (less than £20 each) and fortunately the opera had british supertitles (I would have struggled without them I think). We used trip advisor to find seats that we could afford with reasonable prices so check on here before you book online with mariinsky. We even picked up a programme in english and borrowed opera glasses for £2 a lend from the cloakroom. Only tip, ladies use the loo before you visit, queues were almost as magnificent as the opera at every break!

A Great Performance. Despite my love of music and my frequent visits to the Opera in various parts of the world, this was my first visit to the Ballet - La Bayadere.The theatre is magnificent and lived up to expectations, except that the chairs in our box were hard and uncomfortable (a bit like the chairs around a kitchen table and not designed for sitting through a three hour performance).However, the discipline and artistry of the performers more than made up for the discomfort.

Wonderful experience. We saw the Tale of Tsar Soltan at this beautiful theatre. It was a lovely experience - they had English sub-titles to help those who did not understand Russian. the acting was superb. We are glad we went even though it was a bit expensive.

Worth the $, even at Tourist Rate. We made a point of seeing the ballet at Mariinsky I and we're not sorry. We bought tickets well in advance. The online ticketing system did not work by itself, but after we contacted the website by email, things worked out. We paid for the best seats and found ourselves in the third row orchestra. The seats were wooden chairs with a pad on the seat, but quite comfortable.Russian citizens pay a much lower ticket price, so you may find yourself among local ballet lovers, but there are also a lot of tourists. It's worth dressing up and it's the right thing to do; some of the locals appear in a nice dress or sports coat and some dress up; some of the tourists come in nice casual dress, but most have a little more respect.We have only seen a few ballets in the US, but the Russians were much better dancers than we've seen at home. Just the regular company when we went, but great dancers, excellent production.
Unbelievable ballet. We saw Le Corsaire. Performance amazing. New Mariinsky Theatre opened recently. Can't see into Old Theatre unless you attend performance.

A great evening out!. A great evening out! The price was amazing for us as we watched an opera in the royal box costing only £30 (compared with the prices in west end)!! The theatre is stunning, letting you walk around it in the interval. We researched the story of the opera before hand however, did not need it as they had english subtitles at the top of the stage. A must see in st.petersburg whether its a ballet or opera!
Probably amongst the best opera houses in the world. I went to both the "old" and the "new" Mariinsky. The sound of the latter is perfect but I prefer the ambiance of the old one.

The new theatre was a bit disappointing. I attended the ballet at the new Mariinsky Theatre. I found the style of the new building to be out of touch with the surrounding areas and was disappointed not to have been able to see a show in the old theatre. The facilities were good and the whole process of booking, access etc worked well for me as a non-Russian speaker but unfortunately the experience felt like it could have been anywhere other than St Petersburg.
Opera again. We visited twice. Seats are not expensive. Voices good. Catering delicate and good. However for my money I would prefer the old theatre with its passe- ness.

Wonderful Experience. Saw Swan Lake. Had good seats for a price that would be ridiculously cheap in Covent Garden. Dancers just took this to another level. The theatre is very beautiful on both the inside and outside

Go for the experience, bring something to sit upon. The theatre is charming for it's age and history. My experience there was reasonably annoying. In the ENTIRE place - all of the theatre - there is but one ladies rest room (3 stalls) to be found. The chairs aren't theatre chairs, they are single wooden chairs. They are distractingly uncomfortable. The performances we enjoyed but energetically were a bit poor.

Must see the ballet!. We saw Giselle on the opening night. You must check your coats on arrival./ The chairs on the floor level are quite comfortable/ Dress is more formal here than in New York or Paris/ Book tickets in advance online for a ballet in the old theater. Beautiful! Best in the world.

Beethoven Magic. attended a Beethoven symphony and was left spell bound.its one stirring experience and the new Mariinsky is probably the best theatre that exists in the world.its modern, chic and extremely functional. You have to be there to experience the grandeur.

Gorgeous Building!. Visited St Petersburg in September 2013! I loved walking the city by foot and on my list of architectural masterpieces to visit was the original Mariinsky Theatre! I say original because there has been a new one that has opened that bears the name Mariinsky II. My interest was the original older building and I loved the architectural design and got some great photographs.This location is opposite the St Isaac's Cathedral which made an easy visit to do the two at the same time. I took a pre-arranged car from my hotel at a reasonable price for a business associate and myself and enjoyed the convenience of being dropped right outside and snapping a few pics and then back in the car again.It's a magnificent building, has a great history and I was delighted to have visited it.

Unmissable. It was the ambition of a lifetime to see ballet at the Mariinsky, and I wasn't disappointed. I also loved seeing opera at the new Mariinsky II, even though I'm not an opera-lover. Top quality the performers, sets and costumes.

Catch a performance.. The Mariinsky's history rightly draws plenty of attention, but you should really treat yourself to a night at the opera or ballet there -- the quality of the performers is truly world-class. If you do, go early and have a look around the lobby and marvel at the artists who have worked there over the years. Not easy to get to unless you're lodged nearby; the metro is a 20 min. walk, so a bus or taxi are your best bets.

The most amazing Lake Swan ever. Got a ticket for the show the same day in a kiosk by Nevsky prospect (by the yellow building full of stores), really paid a small amount of money and the show I've seen completely blew me away...amazing..beyond words...just perfec Russian Ballet...everything you can imagine it to be. Also the building is beautiful, the staff is very nice and at the break you can actually eat smoked salmon on toasts (it was practically what they only had!) really...only a few bucks and sooo good!

Historic Theatre of Opera and Ballet. Opened in 1860 the Mariinsky is the preeminent theatre of Russia. We attended a performance of "Madama Butterfly" which was extraordinary. It is beautifully laid out - the fabulous boxes of the Russian Czars and Catherine the Great. A true treasure and a must see!
two evenings in a row. A visit to these theaters was our main objective for this visit. Wonderful acoustics and two excellent performances by the Rotterdam Philharmonic Orchestra.

Reminded me of New York's Lincoln Center. We saw an wonderful performance of Verdi's Otello! It's laid out really well and there seemed to be good visibility from most of the seats! It was an all around great experience!

MARIINSKY. Don't leave the city without seeing a ballet in this historic theatre! Tickets can be bought on the internet, where you can be informed about the performances during your visit. Don't mix the old Mariisnky with the modern Mariinsky II. Go for the old one!

See the original production and enjoy newest facilities. I saw the ballet "Nut Cracker", performed by Vaganova Ballet academy, provides most of balletina to Mariinsky Ballet.The performance was wonderful as good as you watched DVDs.Also, I saw the Opera "Otello", new production in Mariinsky2 Theatre, opened May, 2013.Stage is more exciting than Broadway musical, and music sound is more confortable I expected.If you have time, I recommand Old Mariinsky theatre as well as Mariinsky2 Theatre.

a MUST. was on a trip with my wife and we wanted to see Black Swan. we spent the money on the balcony seat as it was our first time and probably one of the last time we see a ballet so we thought better enjoy it.it was quite amazing, very emotional moment... my wike was crying at moment was it was so pretty.From the balcony, the main difference is that you can see the orchestra and you are sure to be able to see everything.

Essential vist if you are in St Petersburg. I purchased tickets for the La Sylphide online prior to arriving in St Petersburg. The interior of the building is spectacular, especially the large chandelier in the middle. In terms of dress code, I wore a smart shirt, shoes and a pair of jeans. Most people were smart casual I'd say, rather than overly dressed.

Aida in Style. You could have been in any opera house in the world but for the Russian subtitles displayed above the stage. However the performance, both opera and dance routines, were stunning. The audience were very appreciative and unpretentious - not a penguin suit in sight. Families, couples and others all enjoying a cultural night out. A truly dramatic experience.

Figaro in Marininskly Theatre. Excelent theatre, exellent interiors and show. It was 3 hrs world wide known Mozart's opera. Music and artists voices were excellent. Buffet is quite expensive, but it is theatre, not restaurant ;) There is the best theater in St. Petersburg and the St/ Petersburg is the best city in Russia. You MUST see it and buy a ticket to enjoy the show and interiors of the building.

Saw the Nutcracker. Dress up for this, you can and will not feel out of place. Loved everything about it. You can easily get a drink and sit down after each part as there is a bar and toilets at every level- GB read this!

Great opera, great ballett. While you are visiting St Petersburg, be sure to get tickets to the greatesr operahouse on earth.
This is the former Kirov.

Definitely recommended even if you don't think you're into ballet. This was a fantastic experience even for people with little knowledge of ballet. The atmosphere was very inclusive - some people in furs and diamonds, some in jeans and t shirts, everything in between, everyone just there to enjoy the ballet. The theatre is magnificent and the performance (Giselle) was, of course, spellbinding. Interval drinks and snacks were surprisingly reasonably priced. We had bought tickets on line directly from the theatre website in advance - good seats for GBP 34 per head. Tip: the confirmation email is not the ticket. You need to log in with the code they send you and print e-tickets. Definitely recommended even if you don't think you're into ballet.

Kirov ballet is incredible. Incredible experience if you can get tickets and if you lucky that the Kirov Ballet is not touring. Its good if you can get tickets thru the hotel concierge and its wonderful St Petersburg experience

Attended 3 ballets in October!!. I attended La Sylphide, Giselle (with Diana Vishneva) and Swan Lake. Theatre is historic and gorgeous. Amazing experience with Swan Lake: Sitting in a 99% Russian audience, with Russian orchestra playing Tchaikovsky for Russian dancers...wonderful!

Fantastic experience. Had a night at the Ballet here. What a great experience. The theatre is just stunning. I enjoyed the cultural experience of both the Ballet and the theatre itself. Have a night of culture and go to this theatre. Recommended activity!And after the theatre... cross the road and have a post theatre meal (or coffee or drink) at the Teatro Cafe. Also a great spot!

Russian Ballet at its best. The ballet in Russia is a vey different experience to anywhere else in the world. So much more cosmopolitan and the audience really knows the good from the bad. We saw an opera we didn't now well (Baladayer) but this did not detract from a super night out.

Speachless!. Been to the "Swan Lake" yesterday night. Not for the first time, but still you feel like in a fair tale. Ballet and decorations are great. Service improved all around with the nice cafe, etc. Everybody smiling. Old building makes you feel like a royalty. If there is only place you go in St. Petersburg - go there!

Marilinsky II theatre. We attended a ballet primiarily to see the building which was designed by a Toronto architect. The ballet was OK, the building magnificent. Prices for non Russians are about twice the price the locals pay - 7200 roubles for two first balcony centre tickets or about $250 Cdn.

Superb ballet ! We were fascinated. We styed for 4 nights and chose the ballet Giselle at the Marinsky. The theater itself is very prety with gold decorations. We sat at the orchestra and were mesmerized by the lightness, skillfullness and beautiful wardrobe. It is a MUST go !

Quite a letdown. Being regular opera-goers, once we got to St. Petersburg, we made it a point to get tickets to whatever was showing at this theatre during our stay. Finally, we were able to purchase 'parterre' tickets for Aïda and were anticipating a lovely evening - on a par at least with the Opera in Paris or the Met in New York..Well, what a let down! Firstly, the seats were of the stiff chaise kind, not fold-over ones, so that every time people came to claim their seats in one's row, it was a convoluted exercise for one to let them pass! Secondly, I do think many spectators (esp.the young) go to this house to see and be seen; their smartphones were switched on most of the time. I saw a woman regularly checking her messages, and another couple checking his! Twice, two women behind us let their phones ring shrilly (and the second time during Aïda's plaintive aria 'O Patria mia'). I angrily turned to shush them and at intermission time scolded the younger girl. It is incredible to note that they are all dressed to the nines but do not seem not to have any idea as to how to behave at the opera.The production - it seemed to me - was one taken from mothballed trunks - all very Cecil B. De Mille - the principal singers were fine although the Amonasro seemed a bit fatigued and could not emit all his notes. I was amazed that Aïda -who sang better - got one flimsy bouquet while Amneris collected 2 great big ones (btw to me the orchestra only had one tone: loud).Getting to the women's toilets was a military exercise in itself; the theatre is a labyrinth of corridors and stairs and nooks and crannies and no useful signage. But we liked the little 'cafés' sprinkled all over where one could get fresh refreshments (there were 3 intermissions after all) and stretch one's legs after sitting in those cramped wooden seats. Regrettably unlike the Opéra Garnier, it does not have (we did not see one anyway in the crush of crowds) a long gallery where one could walk around and appreciate the gilded cherubs overhead, nor little balconies where one could people-see while sipping one's glass of champagne!Ahh, there is still nothing to be compared with the Paris Opera; there, spectators immediately switch off their phones, religiously follow each aria (one can hear the proverbial pin drop), and treat the theatre, the work and the artists with the respect and awe they deserve.

La Boheme. What an amazing experience :) We attended the Mariinsky theatre for a performance of La Boheme. Magical. My daughter had booked from home. Tickets were delivered to our hotel and pickup arranged for 7pm. Beautiful theatre, full of atmosphere. Lots of local people, fantastic stage setting and wonderful singing. Go and see before the 'new' one opens because nothing could compare to this beautiful place. I really hope to go back one day.

Catch the Kirov if you can!. Saw a production of La Bayadere that was simply incredible. This company is beyond world class. The original theater is beautiful. Note that they are about to open a new modern Marinsky behind the original. Try to see a performance in the old theater as it is lovely.

If you don't go to the Marinsky, why are you in St. Petersburg?. Add my name to the list of people translated into another dimension by Osipova's sublime rendition of Giselle. And I suspect that just about any performance in this hall will be great. A note: The old Marinsky has been joined by a "New Marinsky". To sip of the cup of history you will want to ensure you get tickets for a performance in the old hall although I suspect that the creature comforts are better in the new and the performance quality just as good. Buy tickets ahead on-line. Get seats in the elevated perimeter (as opposed to the orchestra level where the seats are in fact level with the person in front obscuring your view). Both the building and performance are well worth the rather substantial cost.

One of the great Theatres of the world. No trip to St Petersberg is complete without a visit to this magnificent Opera House and home to the Kirov ballet. Although the place is packed with tourists there is still a large Russian audience who know their ballet and their opera. Standards are high and the interior is dazzling.

A Must See. One of the most beautiful theaters in the world. Perfectly restored to original opulence. Its ballet company, the Marinksy, formerly the Kirov is deservedly regarded as one the the top 5 companies in the world.
Go to Both!. We saw a ballet (Romeo and Juliet)at MII and loved it - wish we had gone to opera at MI. Walked here from our hotel (Domina Prestige)

A must when in St Petersburg. We were lucky enough to see Natalya Osipova in Giselle which was a wonderful treat. She's fabulous and the Royal Ballet should be thrilled to have her (Russia's loss).Be advised to buy your tickets online well in advance in order to get good seats. When selecting a ballet, pay attention to the local i.e. old or new Mariinsky (Mariinsky II is the modern theatre). And do dress nicely for the evening. It is a shame to see some of the audience in jeans and sneakers. The tickets are not inexpensive, the local is superb and it's an once in the lifetime experience for most so dress for the occasion!

Ballet brilliance. Not a ballet buff, but the Mariinsky is not to be missed. The ballet was amazing - the props extraordinary and the historic theatre amazing. While it could use a little renovation, it is entirely affordable for anyone to see. Not what I can say of most theatres around the world. For a seat above the dress circle, with excellent views to the stage, but perhaps not the most comfortable seat after 3.5 hours, one would pay around 600RB or about $25USD. Fantastic value. For more comfortable seats and lower seating, the ticket prices become comparable to other cities around the world. Not to be missed if you are in St Petersburg

Worth visiting. I just wish I spoke fluent Russian or German.... I came here a little while back with family and friends. At the time, they were doing the German Opera "Die Frau ohne Schatten" (The Woman without a Shadow) by Wagner. In summary:Pros:Mariinsky is an amazing theatre to visit. Wonderful architecture inside and outside to see. With such history. The opera was put on beautifully. Great production with a great cast who sung very very well. Cons:Unfortunately for us, we saw a German opera. Which had Russian subtitles. And we spoke neither, we saw in the audience for almost 2-3 hours completely bored stiff, as we were unable to comprehend anything. We actually went with some Venezuelan and Spanish friends. And they could not understand German or Russian either. They managed to only sit thru 30-45 minutes worth of the opera before they just got up and left. They couldn't take 2-3 hours of constant German with Russian subtitles. In summary. This is a beautiful building. Worth visiting. Just make sure you see a production that is in a language you understand. Alternatively, you could go see Ballet or Tchaikovsky. That would be much more enjoyable.

Transported Into a Fairytale. The Mariinsky Theatre is just beautiful. The acoustics are perfect, the orchestra is sublime, and I've never seen anything that compares to the Kirov Ballet Company. What fairytale magic, what grace, what beauty! Wow. This woman right here-->http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natalia_Osipova--who performed the lead in Giselle tonight--I've never seen anything like her my whole life. When she dances, it's as if she's a feather, just floating on the stage. Watching her is like watching a beautiful sunrise. There wasn't a dry eye in the Tsar's Box when she danced tonight. This, this is what I think ballet is supposed to be like. The music, her dancing, the fairytale scenes. It's hard to explain but it almost was like she wasn't human, she wasn't dancing, she was something more than that. She was magical.

Old bu still grand. My husband and I were delighted to see the Kirov Ballet (Giselle) at the Old Marinsky Theater. The seats are old and slightly uncomfortable. However, the theater has been renovated and has a wonderful stately feeling that enhances the experience. The acoustics were superb, enabling us the enjoy the musicians as much as the ballet. Don't miss this, just because it is not "new".

Last night of the season. We bought Russian visas so we could explore St Petersburg and especially because our cruise visit coincided with the last night of the opera season (ballet already finished). The new opera house which is at the back of the old one is beautiful, and really easy and friendly to go to. We saw la Traviata and it was a totally memorable night.

Brilliant. Our two visits were highlights of our Russian holiday. The quality of everything was superb, and and the audience reactions made it an even better experience.Warning- the slope on the stalls is minimal and the chairs are directly in line with those in front. On one occasion we were in the most expensive seats but could see very little through the head of the person in front. Next time we would choose one of the circles.
Giselle at Mariinsky. Balletomane's heaven. What more can I say? The epitome of ballet blanc, with spirit under the perfect surface.

A chance to see the Mariinsky (Kirov) Ballet? You bet!. Got a last minute ticket to see Giselle on Saturday night for R680. I am not a big ballet goer, but fancied a bit of culture for a change. The Mariinsky is home to the today's global choreography of Giselle and has seen many of the World's best known dancers pirouette and plie across its boards.My seat was in the most upper circle, hence the price, and seating was an upholstered bench, so not the most comfortable, but not worth moaning about at the price. Being so high I got a pretty good view of the stage and the dancers, and only the 2 flights on wires were partly obscured.The performance was superb and this was a great experience out of the norm for a business traveller.If you can get a ticket - go see it!

Splurge & go. Even if you have seen either the ballet or opera company elsewhere, their home theatre is special. It is a room full of history & magic. You can see a model of it to the right of the booking window, so you can see exactly where your seat will be.

It was ok.... The theatre was nice, but the seats were horrible. Our bottoms were hurting so bad! We went to Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow and the seats were so comfortable. This theatre definitely needs a makeover.

One of the highlight of our trip. We were able to get great tickets through Red October, our private tour company. The theatre is truly amazing. The ballet was one of the best I've seen. It will remain forever imprinted.

A Grand Old Theater. If you have the chance to catch a ballet or concert at the Mariinsky theater, grab it! We saw the ballet Romeo and Juliet which was wonderful, though long (it had 2 intermissions!) The seats are wooden chairs, but were pretty comfortable. Most of the people were quite dressed up though you still saw some tourists in blue jeans and flannel shirts. There is a bar inside, but hugely expensive. One glass of nearly flat champagne was $20. Other than that, it's a beautiful theater and seeing a Russian ballet is a wonderful night out.

Great evening of ballet. The new Mariinski theater is a lovely, modern setting for the Kirov Ballet. I am not a great judge of ballet, but my wife is. She thought the production was entertaining and that the performers were technically excellent. i often sleep in ballets, but I saw most of this one. By the way, this is not an inexpensive proposition. We sat in the second balcony; cost per seat was $185. So you know.

Dreamy!. Although the ballet wasn't due to open until after I left, I heard a marvelous Makbet (Macbeth) opera in the old (classic) theater. I hear that the acoustics are astounding at the new theater, which is very contemporary. But I was very happy in the old theater. Great people-watching the international, stylist patrons. This is a must see while in St. Petersburg. In the city. but not very near metro or buses, so I pre-booked a cab, since I was traveling solo.

Wonderful. Seeing the ballet was top of my list for our St Petersburg trip and I was thrilled that we were able to get tickets for the Mariinsky as the theatre itself is so amazing. We prebooked on the theatres website and just printed off e tickets. We chose the the third row (elevated) seats on the Belle Etage level, box 10 and were delighted with the view and felt it was excellent value compared to the seats one row in front which were dearer and not elevated. We had taken dresses and heels and were glad to have made the effort as most people were dressed up. The area around the theatre was very quiet, not what we had expected being used to Londons theatre area but after a little walk towards the St Nicholas Cathedral and then over the canal we found a nice resteraunt for our pre show tea.

pretty building. Another pretty wedding-cake like building. Unfortunately it was closed as it was summer. We were hoping that there would at least be tours- but sadly not- so had to contend with the outside

Worth persevering with buying a ticket. Went directly to the Mariinsky Theatre (bus #27 from Nevsky Prospect) to buy a ticket. Saw a lavish production of a Tchaikovsky opera for 300 roubles. The seat was up on 5th tier but view was still good and sound excellent. There was a simultaneous computerised translation which helped. Seats are on hard benches at this price, but it was quite a memorable experience to be there.

How to get ballet tickets for Mariinsky. Many people had difficulty getting tickets for Mariinsky in a decent way, I had it too but now I have found my way and can share it. My first visits I got ticket with ballet&Opera.com and my hotel concierge, they both marked up the true price by 80% - incredible anywhere but probably not for Russia. It is very simple: you first register with the theatre, consult their website and book well ahead in English and paying with credit card. Even if you see a performance that is virtually full, tickets may be further released later. It is very bad that Mariinsky does not release cast till late, unless for superstar shows like Vishneva, but if you consult their website frequently you will see surprises....for example only 3 weeks to show time I found Osipova dancing Giselle and Lopatkina dancing Midsummer Night's Dream just announced (for Oct 2013). Simply, don't buy tickets from a third party unless you want to pay double and can't choose seat as with the thatre direct.......I am returning next month Oct 2013 with good seats in hand paying fair prices....

Queen of Spades. Bought tickets somewhat by chance (got a bit lost looking for a restaurant) for a show that evening but so glad that we did. Our first experience of opera was a great one and cost next to nothing to get in. Orchestra was incredible! The four hours (!) flew by. Not especially easy to get to if travelling by metro - a good 15-20 minute walk from closest stop. Drinks expensive so worth taking a bottle of water.

Classical Experience. A great choice of opera and ballet is on offer throughout the year by the world famous Kirov company. Each production is a supreme experience - even if you do not visit the opera or ballet regularly, do take the opportunity to enjoy one of the world's best when you are in St Peterburg - it will be an experience you will never forget. The theatre itself has been refurbished in recent times, but retains much of its original splendour and opulence.

Use the website. It is terrific. Two important things: the New Mariinsky (Mariinsky II) is wonderful. All seats are comfortable, their are elevators, a great new hall. The old Mariinsky is a museum piece, beautiful but the cheap seats are uncomfortable and seats to the sides may have terrible sight lines.The website is terrific! You can identify and purchase available seats in both theaters. Tickets may be available even on day of performance. The quality of production and performance are world class, although they do program some pretty tired and/or obscure 19th century Russian work.There are 2 prices for all but cheap seats, the less expensive one for those residing in Russia. The cheap seats in Mariinsky II are very good.I went almost every night for a week!
Romeo and Juliet ballet. WOW! there is really not many word to describe the experience of going to the ballet. The music, the dancers, the costumes, the old theater..all of it was breathtaking

Amazing. The new building is so beautiful inside that you should visit it even if you not planning to watch anything (although I don't know if they let you in without a ticket).
We went to see Iolanta opera.
Ballet. Saw Swanlake Had champagne in intermission.Orchestra was great,costumes outstanding and the ballet Swanlake was phenomenal.A wonderful experience
Swan Lake can never be performed too often. Had the pleasure of seeing the local ballet company. My only complaint was that the air conditioning was weak
A Once in a Lifetime Experience. We saw Sleeping Beauty and it was magnificent. Even the non-ballet fans were happy. The theatre is a show in itself.

Russian Ballet in its best. When you hear "Ballet" you think of Russians, right? Talented dancers, sounds of wonderful live orchestra, old building that saw tzars and their favorites - nothing beats "The Swan Lake" in Mariinsky! If you are a ballet person you absolutely have to see it there!
New theatre - great acoustic. Was a bit disappointed that couldnt see the ballet in the old theatre, but the new one has a great acoustic and comfortable seats. Definitely a must in St Petersburg.

The MOST AMAZING Dancers I have EVER seen in my life.. If you want to see the WORLDS BEST Dancers....this is the place to go. The command of their bodies and technique was ABSOLUTELY AMAZING. Their ability was so far above the average professional dancer it boggled my mind. And most amazing was their ability to relay EMOTION. Every part of their body articulated, like a novel or movie filled with pure emotion, intrigue, interest, story, drama, joy simply MAJESTIC. I have never seen dancers who captured me this deeply....ever.I saw Giselle which was classic and perfect, But really go over to the New theater to see some of the NEW Ballet works they do. Still technically a ballet style but they are going into other realms of movement that are just amazing and so well expressed...enthralling.

The most enchanting, outrageously great performances.. Saw a performance of the firebird in March 2013. I promise you, the ballerina was magical. She actually seemed like she was flying, without any cables. The set were stunning and entertaining. The beautiful building, the crowds, the pre performance drinks all make the experience even better. The tickets are easy to get online and most of the seats have good viewing. So it's a good experience on any budget. One of the best things about this experience? People watching and seeing those adorable Ruasian teenagers on their first dates. It's really nice that young people seem to like the arts.
A must see. Great performances with great orchestra. Make sure you buy your tickets in advance as the shows get sold out easily.
One of the best ballet in the world. And probably the best classical ballet in the world. Watch out for performances with Lopatkina or Vishneva

swan lake. enjoyed it ,theatre has old world charm
got impression folks are allowed to smoke in the vicinity waiting areas,though not inside ,
the performance was very good.
would not recommend for children even teenagers, who enjoyed it initially but found it to be too long

Wonderful. It is easy to book tickets online, just make sure you do not select the cheapest tickets as the asterisk means that they are for Russians only and they do check identification for these tickets. That said, our tickets had a bar code, so we did not need to exchange our printed out tickets for official tickets. We had a box seat which faced the middle of the stage. The seats were great but be aware that if you are in the second or third row of a box, that your view can be obstructed by the people in the front row. The theatre is not air conditioned: we visited on a cool evening in July so it was not an issue that night.The doors to the performance hall open about 15 minutes before the start time, arriving early gives you time to admire the theatre.Our cruise boat was docked at the English Embankment and it was an easy walk back to the boat (if you have Russian visas).Highly recommend.

Spectaclular. We went to see the Don quixote ballet after buying tickets from Australia. However you can get cheap tickets on the night if you just turn up. By cheap I mean $100. Its spectacular inside and the ballet excellent.
saw Swan Lake - spectacular. between the setting and the show - this was a great highlight of the trip! Well done on all levels -

A Must See for Any Visitor!. Easy to book tickets online and pick up at "Will Call"Tickets are pricey, but you should know that already; completely worth the experience!Sat in the Bel-Etage... ...seats in this section give an amazing view, but are not that comfortable. Anyone sitting here with back/leg problems would do good be bringing something soft to sit on. Our visit was during the summer and the theater got quite warm.Take time before the show to visit the reception rooms and the displays in them. You will not have a chance after the show as the ushers are quick to shut everything down.The performance we saw, Le Corsair, was outstanding! Amazing dancers and musicians!We are so glad to have experienced an integral piece of St. Petersburg's history!

Two nights in a row!. Saw Marriage of Figaro then Swan Lake the following night. Our opera seats were better, right beside the Presidential Box. I wish I had splashed out equally for the ballet. We went on a night when the principal dancers were performing ... wow. I've never seen anything like it, Ekaterina Kondaurova dances to the tips of her fingers and toes. A super experience in one of the world's most famous theatres.
a must. It is just great!!! From beginnning to the end. Wonderful performance - the Swan lake. Price of the ticket was 105$ each.

MacBeth. We were excited to see a Russian opera, so went to see Macbeth.We were hoping to see a very old theater, but this was a newer one build 50 yrs or so ago and lacked the opulence of old theaters. The music and vocalists were wonderful but my friends were very surprised that there was no scenery nor costumes that would have helped tell the story. Overall, the performance was great, but lacked the wonderful costumes that they displayed in their lobby. Cost was over $129, so not inexpensive.

A night at the opera. So easy to book on the net and the e-tickets absolutely reliable. Even if you don't speak or read Russian the usherettes are most helpful to get you to your right seat. Wonderful orchestra and music. Chairs look lovely, but so hard. Take something for your back! (This is the 'old'Mariinsky' - there are probably more comfortable seats in the Mariinsky 2).

Russian ballet at its finest. We attended Swan Lake at Marrinsky 1 and it surpassed all of our expectations. The best ballet i have ever seen. We were not disapointed by our seats at the "bel etage". Although the seats are pricey for a foreigner, I would avoid any seats higher t than the bel-étage. The surprise of our trip!

My fav theatre. I have seen several operas here and love it! breathe in the cultre, but be aware, the seats are a tad hard and my bum gets a bit numb by half time! seats by the royal box are cheap but perfect!

Don't hesitate to go!. We booked our tickets online before travelling to St Petersburg: the website was very easy to use and we simply presented our documents at the ticket office with our passports to gain our tickets prior to taking our seats. We saw Giselle and, despite the main company being on tour, the quality of the performance was superb. It was one of the highlights of a really good week in this beautiful city.

Ballet Raymonda. We saw the ballet Raymonda at the Mariinsky Theatre on September 19, 2012. It was the first ballet staged after the summer break. And the only one that could fit our schedule as it was our last night in St. Petrsburg. The role of Raymonda was played by Olesya Novikova. We got tickets direct from the Mariinsky box office thru the internet which costs Roubles 500 each. We were seated at the stalls middle row 2 which was very near the stage so we can see even the faces of the dancers quite clearly. We almost bought our tickets from a website which were selling the tickets at more than 5 times the box office price. Good we learned that we can buy the tickets direct from the Mariinsky website. It was exciting to be at the theatre if only because of it's rich history and it's reputation as Russia's premiere ballet theatre together with the Bolshoi. The play itself was quite old fashioned and to be honest, somewhat politically incorrect (with a dark moor being the villain). While Olesya was a very good dancer, I thought she lacked expression. Afterwards, we headed back to the hotel in our pre-arranged privately- owned BMW ( there appears to be no taxis in Russia) which we hired courtesy of our hotel doorman. All in all, we had a very memorable evening.

Spartacus, so worth it. The play was amazing, the music impressive, the actors so talented, but: the food that you can buy during the rest periods its so expensive. Also we expected to see the play at the old theater because of the atmosphere and decoration, and the play was on the new one, but still very nice theater. We bought the tickets on the same day and it was 72euros aprox each.

Ballet in Summer. Going to the ballet at the Mariinsky Theatre feels like travelling back in time to the days of Anna Karenina. There feels to be a ceremony to getting dressed up and going to watch Bolshoi stars dance. The sets were absolute works of art, as were the costumes. The dancers were superb. The entire evening was fun and even the interval food (cream cheese and caviar on bread) left nothing to be desired.

A great experience if you love theatre, but be prepared for surprises.. We saw Mozart's "Marriage of Figaro" - a fine production in terms of the music, singing, and the set, but the wardrobe department has seemingly yet to recover from the fire they had a few years ago.The seats (in the stalls, at least) are fixed wooden-framed dining room chairs with arms (often called "carver" chairs) which some may find a little less comfortable than traditional UK theatre seating.During the tourist season, many audience members are likely to be unused to going to theatres and be lacking the usual etiquette, so be prepared for people talking during the performance and even flash photography ( rather like the Royal Shakespeare Theatre in Stratford upon Avon in high summer).

theater is opulent. Go to old one not the new one they constructed recently. The old one is beautiful. Plan ahead if you are there in summer season, as good tickets are hard to come by. Ballet we saw was simply marvelous. An experience that is far richer than what you see when they travel to America or other places.

Birth place of a swan. Marinski is a legendary place as it is where numerous composer and choreographs have been performing over more than a century. This beautiful architecture is a piece of Italy in the middle of the city. the tickets are not too expensive for the qality of the show performed (it was Swan Lake).You can book in advance on internet as sometimes it could be fullvery quickly when the big vruise ships are docking in St Petersbourg

Anna Karenina. What a brilliant occasion - ballet at its best in what is probably one of the best opera houses in the world. If you do nothing else book a night at the Mariinsky Theatre you will not regret the decision.
Musical events. Mariinsky 2 is breathtaking. Melomaniacs will enjoy top quality performances of classical music, opera and ballet.

Classic and Elegant Theater. If you enjoy ballet or have a small interest in the ballet you should definitely buy tickets to see a performance. The ballet theater is an elegant setting and, of course, the troupe is first class. It is best to buy your tickets ahead of time at the Mariinsky Theater web site (www.mariinsky.ru). Often the better seats are not available within a few days of a performance and certain performances sell out quickly.
must do. we thoroughly enjoyed the ballet. we went to the new theater and my 12 and 14 year old admitted that it was nice. You are in St. Petersburg. Go to the ballet!

Marinsky 2 the new theatre.. Having already booked two ballets and an opera we wanted more and tried to get tickets for Tosca at the Marinskiy 2. Two days before the performance we were told that all tickets were sold out. We were nearby on the day of the performance and made one final enquiry and found that two tickets were available in Box D which was a central box about halfway up with a good view. Price was 3400 Roubles about £68 each and it must be said that the seats are much wider than usual and very comfortable. They have a wide selection of quality refreshments available but the queue for the ladies restrooms was as bad as ever. The opera was first class and it's delivery surpassed even the highest expectations. Don't give up at the first hurdle as perseverance often pays off.
Superb. See the ballet Giselle was exciting, superb show in the splendid frame of the magnificent theater for the show during the White Nights! We liked very much!

Must-see attraction. Mariinski theatre (also known as the Kirov Ballet) is a brand of St.Petersburg. It is absolutely “must-see” when you are in St.Pete. There are 3 stages now: an old stage in a gorgeous historical building, a brand new stage 2 in ugly modern building nearby, and concert hall, which is also not far from the old stage. The best time to visit is May-July during "White Nights festival". The ballets are traditionally very good, thanks to principal conductor Valery Guerguiev, the operas are getting better and better. The best musicians come to play in the concert hall. The best way to get tickets is via Internet. The Mariinski theatre’s website is in Russian and English, there you can find the playbill, information on shows, synopsis, and can easily buy tickets with you credit card (it is safe, I personally did it several times). Do not forget to check if you need Russian visa beforehand.

Beautiful. We attended an evening which consisted of two one act ballets. They were contemporary ballets and thoroughly enjoyable. The theatre itself is beautiful. We arrived by taxi and then walked to the Metro to return to our hotel.
Great ballet. Kirov ballet is excellent, very professional. The theater is really beautiful. the audience is good, no noise are inappropriate behavior, had a great experience there.very recommended.
The nut cracker. You cant go to Russia and not watch ballet. Had the pleasure of watching the nut cracker.A beautiful theatre and a good performance.

Worth seeing threatre. It is beautiful threatre looks like a palace, it is best to become a member and then book ticket online and you get e ticket. So hassle free you can print you ticket. More than the ballet it is experience to see threatre.

Fantastic Experience. Fantastic experience for a fraction of the price paid at the Bolshoi in Moscow. We walked in and were able to get tickets for the Don Quixote ballet in the front row of the Emperor's box (which were the best seats in the theatre) for £50 each.

Don Quixote event!. Just experienced a quite superb night at the ballet
Great atmosphere and an exceptional quality performance particularly from the 2 lead principal dancers
Very colourful costumes-a really "feel good event" which would be enjoyed by all
A highlight of our stay in St Petersburg!

Don Quixote. Beatifull balley!
But beware! they pack boxes really tight. they put 3 rows of seats where used to be two. there is no space for you knees at all.
Unfortunately this greed spoils the beauty.
not to be missed opera or ballet in this place. we could have tickets for an opera (il viaggo to Reims). A great experience. the tickets can ve bought on Internet

Perfect way to see Swan Lake, best price to book through theatre not online. It was a beautifully decorated ornate theatre that was less than 2 blocks from our hotel, Hotel Rossi, which was on the same block as the ballet school that serves the theatre. We had the hotel desk contact the theatre directly to book the tickets for us and got the first row of box seats (4 seats/box) for ~$65usd per person. This was a steal considering they were going for $120+ online and we had the box next to the presidential box in the center. We even saw the principal male dancer exiting the theatre as we went on a walk later that night.

Ballet was a highlight of our trip. Practicalities: Tickets were booked online in advanced and printed out, meaning that we did not have to go to the ticket office but walked straight in - recommended. (This was during the Star of the White Nights Festival) We were seated at the top level (3rd gallery) and in the 3rd row, tickets cost us 800 rubles. Beforehand, I was worried about the view but it wasn't too bad. It wouldn't have been a problem at all except for the fact that the women in front of me kept leaning forward and blocking a part of the stage. Luckily there were some extra seats and in the first intermission we moved higher up towards the center. This meant we were nearly on the roof, but the view was still fine. I would recommend getting seats in the center section, not the side-wings. If you are in the middle, sitting on the top balcony is OK. But of course if you can afford it, go for seats closer to the stage. I would guess being on the "Belle Etage" or the 1st gallery is excellent. You can see the pictures I took from my seat below.Experience:Having never seen a live classical ballet before I wasn't sure what to expect, especially when I learned the show would all in all take 3 hours. My boyfriend and I had talked about the possibility of leaving during intermission if we found it boring. Needless to say, it never came to that. We saw the Swan Lake and enjoyed it through and through, marvelous performance and beautiful music in the charming surroundings of the old Mariinsky.

Flying Dutchman. The female role was played spectacularly. The males were also good but sometimes overpowered by the orchestra. The seats are not comfortable. There is a background noise that maybe coming from flans in the spot lights. Twice a door could be heard closing backstage during the performance. It is song in germen but the projected translation is only in Russian.

A bit seedy. I saw Carmen at the old Mariinsky, having wanted to vist there forever. The seats in the Theatre are rather uncomfortable and it could use a spruce up. The audience was rather subdued. The Opera house in NY or London is far better

A Theater lead by truly inspired leader. Mariinsky Theatre does it's best to show you best opera and ballet. It organizes world-known season of White Nights Stars, but don't think it's the only time to come. Any time you are in St.P you can visit it and get your portion of emotions :)

A great time at the historic Mariinsky for a Mozart opera. We saw Mozart's Marriage of Figaro from a first tier box at the old Mariinsky - for about $70 US for two tickets. The singers and orchestra were marvelous. The theater itself is gorgeous, if slightly dingy, post-imperial magnificence. Our only complaint were two young women in our box (Russians, I think) who kept taking pictures with their iPad and talking throughout the performance - at least they came late, missing Act 1, and left before the last Act! We had a nice after-theater snack at a restaurant called Cafe Teatro, right across the street from the theater. A high-quality experience - whether you are an opera regular or not!

Great performance, lousy seating. Of course the Mariinsky is a destination in itself and the ballet was magical. However the seats were so close together that I had to give up at the end of the 1st act and stand up for the other two acts. Having paid £180 each for our tickets I thought this was a bit unfair. So beware when you book. Make sure that you are not in a box with 3 lines of seats. If you are looking for a meal before/after your performance try Teatro, just across the road from the theatre. Good food and good value.
Swan Lake. Out of this world. First time we've seen ballet live, what a show. Stars of the White Nights and the Kirev Orchestra conducted by the world renowned Valerie Gerviev. Fantastic

The opera experience of a lifetime.. In the beginning of June saw Aida at the Marinskij theater and to quote my friend, who had seen it from the Metropolitan, it was better than the american version. The balett was fantastic. We didn't have very good seats just by the siden of the orchestra so some of the voices drowned a bit, but the choir was fantastic.

Beautiful Swan Lake. You can order tickets on Line and print your own tickets. Beautiful theatre and performance. Tickets were offered only a month in advance....it may not be that way always...when I knew we were going to St Petes I looked at website every day. Advice about best seats available on Trip advisor forum very helpful. Tickets no more expensive than New York Broadway play.

a soviet era ballet. I went to see the ballet " Fountain of bakchisaray" ...an unseen piece outside Russia..well, for a reason.. It's the less danced ballet I've ever seen..But the experience to be at Mariinsky worted every single penny..Just being there is a unmissable opportunity if you visit Sankt Petersburg
Carmen. We saw Carmen that was 4 hours and 20 minutes and it was absolutely beautiful. I could not believe that my husband sat through the whole production and enjoyed it so much.

Remarkable building. The interior decoration is certainly astounding, although I wouldn't disagree with you if you found it heavy handed. As for the performance (Onegin), just passable, except for Semishkur, a very affecting Lensky.
Fabulous. Saw Ruslan and Ludmilla (Glinka) music divine, stage and costumes colourful, performances brilliant. Very russian so a marvellous experience.
Nutcracker Suite. Wonderful ballet in a gorgeous theatre. Expensive, but money well spent. I doubt I'll ever see classical ballet anywhere again except in Russia.

A night to remember. Went to the Bolshoi while in Moscow however found that the marinsky was a better experience. Got our tickets on line requesting front row seats - they were perfect. Didn't need to lean over to see the stage.

One of the finest theatres in the world. If you have the possibility, go to any performance at the Mariinsky. The acoustic quality of the theatre is amazing and I have never seen a bad performance there. The quality of music is always very high although some productions may be a bit old fashioned. The old theatre itself is something to see and experience, so beautiful, so royal.

Go, even if it is just to see the building. It's probably worth paying for a ticket just to see the inside of the theatre. I went to see Swan Lake and the scale of the performance is probably more impressive than the quality of the dancing - I counted 40 dancers, an orchestra of about 30 but also a few mistakes! The theatre is small, u-shaped and there isn't much banking, so it is probably better to get a front row seat in the middle on a lower balcony. If you are behind someone slightly taller than you in the stalls then your view is obscured. I think the balconies are cheaper than the stalls too. However, don't go for the balcony seats near the stage as you can't see too much due to the angle.All of the seats are effectively dining room chairs which get pretty uncomfortable after 3 hours! There isn't much air conditioning so in the height of summer it probably gets a little unpleasant. Drinks and snacks are expensive (150 roubles for 250ml of water) and the queues can be long but the intervals lasted about 25 minutes during our show and that seemed normal given it ended on time. Have a wander around the inside of the building during the interval as there are lots of interesting nooks and crannies.Having said all of that, it's a good experience and in the summer you get the bizarre experience of exiting into broad daylight after a 3 hour evening performance!

Grand Old Theatre in Saint Petersburg. My wife and I enjoyed the Don Carlos by Verdi opera at the Mariinsky theatre on 3 June in Saint Petersburg, Russia. Unfortunately the A/C was not working well for a hot day!
OPERA!!. The most exhilarating opera I have ever attended. The sets, staging, orchestra... were brilliant. Never miss an opportunity to do this!

A wonderful experience. The old theatre is not exactly designed to give everyone the best view, but is a truly magnificent building. The seats aren't cheap, but the ballet is a great experience and I would thoroughly recommend it. Had to stand up through the performance to get a full view of the stage, which was fine for us, but would not be for others - and to do this you will need a seat without anyone behind you! We had one of the boxes at the side of the theatre on one of the upper levels.

Highlight of our visit. Seeing Swan Lake performed by the Kirov Ballet in the beatiful theater was an exceptional experience. Seats: We had the floor level box, try to stay as close to the center as possible. It is a small theater so these seats are not too far from the stage (even though on the floor plan it appears to be far). The orchestra has very little incline so the boxes on either floor level or level 1 - front row only - provide the best view. Booking Online: This is much less expensive than the agencies.

Top Ballet Performances in the World?. I hadn't been back to the Mariinsky Theatre since 1995. On May 26 I took a group of friends to see The Nutcracker. Of all the ballet performances I have attended, including probably a dozen at the Bolshoi,the two most memorable have been at the Mariinsky. I'm absolutely no expert, but the combination of the theatre, the orchestra, the sets and the dancers were all 5 star.We were able to buy seats for just under $100 per person which was a great value for an unforgettable evening.

THE BEST BALLET COMPANY IN THE WORLD!. Sleeping Beauty was not my favorite ballet until we saw the Mariinsky production...The entire company dances at a level that makes the best American and British ballet companies look amatuer....We sat in the cheapest seats ($165) in the fifth tier which were excellent, but of course we pay considerably more than the Russians...but it was worth every ruble spent....
Mariinsky 2 now open. Wonderful contemporary building. However, the acoustics are awful, so if you want to enjoy opera, keep to the old Mariinsky! Might be better for ballets, probably.

Swan Lake. Bought the tickets online prior to our trip and secured pretty good seats for the price - USD110. Circle seats at the 2nd level, but right at the side of the stage ... No obstructed view and it provided for a very good feel of ballet. We could take in the entire theatre and even see the features of the ballerinas! It was quite a walk from the Metro stop, about 20min at a leisurely pace but we were rushing and by the time we reached, we were all dripping with perspiration. So give yourself ample time for the walk to Mariinsky.

Swan lake 25/5/2013. This was my first visit to a ballet, and I am sold! The Mariinsky theatre was beautiful and the ballet was amazing. I would recommend getting dressed up for it and there is a free cloakroom for coats etc.

An experience not to be missed. The Mariinsky is an institution in St Petersburg which is the cultural heart of Russia. I saw the opera Don Carlo and although it was very long (5 acts), the performers were very good. The chairs are not the most comfortable to sit on for this long, but this is a once in a life time experience. It is also an opportunity to chat to the people you are sitting next to. The cost of the opera was very reasonable compared to other Opera Houses around the world. Don't buy any of the food or drink available at the intervals unless money is no object.

Sleeping Beauty. Allthough the new theatre is ready, our performance took place in the old and lovely Mariinski. The dancers were good (not great), the choreography a bit old-fashioned. Just like the costumes (allmost funny wigs), scenery and lighting (spots handeld by hand). But all together a really historic event! Go and experience the famous Russian ballet you'll feel like you live a hundred years ago!

Excellent - 5 Star. Just excellent, what more is there to say, a must for everyone visiting St Petersburg, I'm sure you will not be disapointed whatever you see in this woundeful building with world class performers.

It is a must.. Try to read more about the shows. I was interested in the famous Kirov Ballet and signed for a performance during my short visit. Unfortunately due to my lack of knowledge I saw a modern ballet ( Stravinsky´s Sacre du Printemps) show instead of a classical ballet which I was really interested in.

Swan Lake. We couldn't not see swan lake at one of the most famous theatres in the world. Beautiful inside, although very very hot, no air conditioning and seats very hard, so numb bum after 3 hours. Stage lighting seemed a little dim but still a wonderful ballet and excellent performance. Not to be missed when in St.P! If u want a meal before or after, we recommend Romeos Bar & Kitchen, 2 min walk and lovely.

Ethereal Beauty ~ Pure Magic!. I had the good fortune of seeing the Kirov Ballet perform in London and their performance was nothing short of SPELLBINDING, marvelous, and entrancing. Their athleticism, grace and beauty is something everyone should have the good fortune to see at least once in their lives. The Kirov is simply without equal.

Should we throw a stone in the Glass house-scene 2?. Newly opened scene 2 of the famous Mariinsky Theatre - it is really a great scene inside, perfect accustics, enormous seat spaces and a vastlty of the foyer decorated with Swarovsky Chandeliers and a huge tall shining sunny-amber-colour onyx wall. Breathtaking.I think it is worthwhile being there and enjoy the operas and ballets. I did and had a great deal of pleasure. Do visit!

Classic classics. If you visit Saint-Petersburg, going to the Mariinsky is a must not only because it is an architectural monument, one of the most beautiful theatre-halls in the world, but also because of a highest professional level of both ballet and opera companies and of course one of the best orchestas on the globe led by Maestro Gergiev. My recent visit was not the first one, despite the fact I live in Moscow, but it was as fabulous as it used to be in the past. And it is worth mentioning that we watched a historic ballet performance 'Don Quixot" by Minkus, which has become a classic one. The scenery, dancing, acting and orchestra playing were superb and me and my daughter enjoyed every minute of it. We look forward to further visits in the future,.The building itself definitely needs renovating, but most of the original features ought to be preserved at any cost. This 'pearl' mustn't be lost forever.

Not so impressed. Having been to St. Petersburg many many years ago previously, I believe the standards the Mariinsky is worse than the Kirov, with standards slipping. Sure, this is still somewhat "the" place to see ballet, but I just think there are other places and attractions that deserve more time on the Saint Petersburg itinerary than this one because Russian ballet frequently goes on tour anyway so you'll have a chance of seeing it in your home town.

New Mariinsky stage - Mariinsky - II (Dekabristov 34a). Opened just recently the new venue became a loving toy for the city inhabitants and its guests: very comfortable for the guests (a lot of modern elevators, stairs, cloak rooms, cafeterias) and presenting marvelous views to the city from the lobby windows! And - not the last to be mentioned- the best sound in the main hall (at least in Russia and, probably, in Europe) and very technically assisted scene and scene light. The opening of the Mariinsky II became a great world opening and provides great opportunity for visiting StPetersburg (see gold-light-emanating onix-marble walls of the main halls at the picture).

Put this theatre on your bucket list!. I've been lucky enough to hear and see performances at this amazing theatre on several occasions. Irrespective of the ballet or opera being performed (and on every occasion they've been magically wonderful), just to be in the audience is an historic experience. The Imperial box still glitters extravagantly; the curtains and chandeliers breathe opulence. No ice cream at the interval - Champagne, caviar and smoked salmon still reign supreme. And by the way, it's not expensive if you have the sense to book direct with the Mariinsky. Shame on the websites which exploit the overseas tourists.

In punta di piedi.... Ballet lovers (and not) you cannot miss the opportunity to be in one of the temple of classic ballet. It is advisable to buy tickets online to ensure the perfect spot to enjoy a magical evening.

old fashioned charm. saw Sleeping Beauty here. Very traditional theatre, with very traditional presentation of the ballet, but all lovely. Lots of little girls (well behaved) in the audience, dressed up in their best, out for a special evening with their families, which was good to see.......

Beautiful interior and excellent ballet. Saw Sleeping Beauty at Mariinsky - interior was beautiful but seating not the most comfortable for a 3h55 minute performance. Really enjoyed the ballet except not sure what was the point of Red Riding Hood, Puss in Boots, white Cat, Bluebird (that looked like A Smurf) other than to showcase more talent - they were good but performance would have been perfect if it ended after 3 hours!

Historic and atmospheric. We saw Nabucco with Placido Domingo - great singing and great to see the old theatre and soak up the atmosphere. However the seats were extremely uncomfortable and the place was hot (hadn't turned on the air conditioning yet) so we suffered physically. We had been at the opening of the new Mariinsky and can see why they need it. (It's gorgeous, modern and comfortable.)

There are 3 Theatres. We attended the new (2006) concert hall of the Mariiinsky Theatre as there was no current performance at the "old" theatre that night. The opera was competent but not world class. Tickets for the opera at the "new" Mariinksy Theatre were prohibitlively expensive the four days we were in St Petersburg.
Giselle. I love ballet and it was a fantastic opportunity to enjoy this beautiful Theatre and Giselle was lovely! The new Mariinsky is ready now and it seems there are lots of discussions about it...

A warning on ticket prices at Mariinski (Kirov) Opera. I attended "The Magic Flute" at the Mariinski Concert Hall on April 25th. I had prepurchased my ticket on the official Mariinski website. My seat was in the "Dress Circle Box A". There is no view of any part of the stage from these seats unless one stands up or, alternatively, leans over the balcony. They are the worst seats in the house and, for the price, probably the worst seats in a modern concert hall anywhere in the world. At the interval I complained at the information desk and was given a seat in the second row of the amphitheatre for the second act - this was theatre in the round and it was great fun to sit on the edge of the stage within touching distance of the performers. Sitting next to me was a young American who lives in St Petersburg. Because he is fluent in Russian he is able to buy tickets at Russian (i.e. non-foreigner) prices. His ticket cost 800 rub. Mine cost 6,480 rub (€162).The following night I attended the venerable old Mariinski Opera House. This I arranged through the concierge at the Astoria. The show was sold out but the hotel has an excellent box and my front row box seat cost me €125.

The best theater in the city and probably in Russia.. Old imperial theater with all the expected elements. Ballets and operas are great. Foreigners have to pay more than locals. You can buy tickets on their website and save on fees often imposed by intermediaries.

Amazing ballet. First time I have ever been to a ballet and was rather apprehensive as to whether I'd like it. However it was one of the most amazing performances I've ever seen that kept me entertained throughout. Amazing dancing and a must see if in Russia.
Tale of Tsar Sultan. Spectacular set and costumes. Excellent singing for this and two other operas we saw. Seats are comfortable in the stalls.
