Shop visit. We did not have time to visit performances, but took a moderate look around and visited small shop in a theatre; place for extremely nice souvenirs!

Astonishing ballet in grand theater. The performance of Swan Lake in this gorgeous old theater could not be topped. The dance company was the most artful, polished and graceful I have ever watched. Best of six times I have seen this ballet. The large stage allows the dancers to perform impressive leaps and masses of swans to gather in lovely symmetry. The prima ballerina did one solo that was sublime. Ten dance of the little swans which requires four swans to dance in perfect synchronicity was executed perfectly. It was the best ballet performance I have witnessed in my 68 years.
Anna Karenina. - wonderful ballet & music, - booking via official website went well- buying really good tickets was certainly not wrong - don't seat in the 2nd or even 3rd row of the loges (boxes)

"Fine company, fine old house". The new building is still not finished, but they were clearly fitting it out when we went; not sure what future arrangements will be, so make the most of the traditional building. The auditorium is smaller than we expected (much smaller than Covent Garden, and not as high as the Coliseum) but that means you get a very good view (as long as you are on the front row). Circulation space is not huge, or particularly grand, but an entertaining warren of arches and staircases.We saw "La Bayadere" which was outstanding, and "Anna Karenina" which was much better than on DVD. Both productions were very good and very well-danced, and the acoustic is very good. It really is a pretty auditorium, shades of peacock-blue and gold.You can get a cast-list and synopsis in English if you ask for it (though most of the staff have little English).The shop turned out to be very disappointing (and only accessible from behind the stalls). No doubt that will change in the new building.We walked to and from the theatre; the scrum for buses coming away was terrible. That will all get much easier when the new Metro station is completed, but I've no idea when that will be.One gets the impression that the company have had to sharpen up a bit now that the Mikhailovsky have improved so much, and I wouldn't put much between them.

A must see. If you go to Russia you have to see the ballet. The seats are wide, velvet-covered individual arm chairs. Go for a seat at least one level up and more towards the center, not the extreme right or left.

Must do in St Petes. Watching the classic Swan Lake ballet at THE Mariinsky Theater is one of the most have experience in a visit to St Petes. Outstanding performance. Can't recommend it enough. I believe it has just completed a refurbishment a year ago and looked wonderful both outside and within. Grand and classic architecture. As with most theaters in Russia, bathroom facilities could be limited. In the theater we saw mostly tourists from the US and Western Europe. Not too many locals were willing to part with USD 200 for a ticket I presume. To get good seats, make sure to pre-book them well in advance. We booked ours almost a month before our departure to Russia.

See it while you can. Construction on the new theater, second stage, is getting closer to completion. Make sure you visit this iconic theater before it's too late. It's location makes for a nice walk as numerous churches and monuments lay within the vicinity, so even if you can't get inside for a tour or a performance, you should still take in it's exterior and the attractions that surround the Theater.

Great building, ballet so-so and VERy sharp elbows in the cloakroom. I bought tickets online from the Mariinsky site which was daunting but possible. We sat in a low level box which was fine if slightly cramped. And it is a lovely building within the theatre though the facilities such as lavatories, cloakroom and bar were very limited and not a good experience.Of course you should go...But we didn't think the first team were on (actually we are nearly sure they were performing in London while we were in Russia) The chorus was ragged and the stars not that compelling. Maybe affected by La Sylphide being short, silly and with no pas de deux.So make sure you have goodish visibility but don't splash out: the actual ballet is now better elsewhere.

Marinsky theatre St Petersburg. I went to this theatre with a friend and saw a production of " the little humped back horse" it is based on an old Russian fairy tale. We shared the theatre with many parents and children dressed up in ballerina costumes! The theatre is beautiful and the production was great, the costuming was wonderful. We arrived by bus which was very easy but managed to get lost walking home, luckily a friendly Russians girl went out of her way to escort us back to our hotel. I arranged the tickets online with the Marinsky theatre company prior to leaving Australian and the tickets were sent to our hotel in St Petersburg .The theatre company booking agency were very helpful, a lady returned my call from Russia who gave me good advice on which theatre to visit. If not for this lady's advice I would not have see a ballet in the main theatre as the website isn't that clear, she informed me that the ballet I had selected was being held in the concert hall and she advised me to go to the main theatre as it was much more beautiful .It was a very enjoyable evening.
Swan Lake. As a part of our river cruise, we were able to go to see the ballet after having dinner at the Tchaikovsky restaurant. The allet was wonderful and a special treat.

World class performances at a very reasonable price. I saw Don Giovanni at the Mariinsky. I purchased the ticket in advance and managed to get a front row seat which allowed me to watch the orchestra as well as the on stage performers.The quality of the performance was world class and the price of the tickets is approximately one third or less of comparable tickets in London or New York. Definitely purchase tickets in advance. I checked the website before my trip and there were still tickets to the ballet available but by the time I arrived the show had sold out and this was in the off season. The theater itself is beautiful. Patrons were dressed from very casual to very formal, but more of the former than the latter so visitors should not feel like they have to get very dressed up to attend a performance.
Great performance!. It's a packed house even on a workday night! The ballet performance is great and the atmosphere is definitely memorable for a visitor!

Mariinsky's lovely sound. Snagged 2 tickets via Marina Wilson Private Tours to a Beethoven/Mahler evening concert. This hall is easy to navigate with all seats seeming to be outstanding. The thing that really makes it a gem though is the perfect acoustics. The sound is pitch perfect and the environ compliments the music beautifully so try to catch even a short concert here, it is lovely.

A highlight of our first visit to Russia. Seeing the ballet (ironically, Ballanchine's Jewels) performed there in February was one of the best things we did during our 4 days in St Petersburg. I purchased tickets (really expensive) on line from the US before we went. Navigating the web site was not easy but was worth the time beause we had fabulous seats right next to the Imperial Box. Be sure to bring some small bills for the coat check lady. We did not have any cash with us, and felt awkward taking our coats into the box with us. No one does that! Also, the program, which is available in English, has to be purchased. This is NOT Broadway!
World Class Ballet. We pre-booked tickets on line (directly with the theater (make sure you use their site) and all worked out very well. Say a superb performance of Swan Lake.

So much more than I hoped for. The Mariinsky theatre is so beautiful, and the Kirov Balley exceeded every one of my expectations. I was lucky enough to see the Nutcracker, and the quality of dance, choreography, set design, and costume design was amazing. Not to be overlooked was the orchestra which was also fantastic. I hope that I have the opportunity to go again!

An Old World Experience. Love the experience of watching a ballet in this theater. We had floor seats in the center 7 rows back. Older theaters don't have as much elevation from the front to the back nor do they stagger seats. Needless to say I was stuck straining around a woman's very large hair style all night and sitting very tall to not only see around her but over her due to the lack in elevation change. I suspect to maintain authenticity they use or have chairs made to look like the ones from a grander time but they are very uncomfortable. Finally, during our performance there were 2 intermissions. Not so bad but the first was for 45min and then the performers came back out for only 30min! Then we had another intermission for 40min. Unnecessarily long.

Prokofiev Romeo and Juliette. The theater is just beautiful, even though it is old fashioned. The performance was just brilliant, both the ballet and the orchestra. Beware that the performances finish rather late , ( 11pm) so you need to eat beforehand. But it is a must see when in St. Petersburg.

An experience not to be missed. Seeing the world famous Mariinsky Ballet is the opportunity of a lifetime, and is not to be missed when visiting St Petersburg. Tickets are easily purchased online (a big benefit over Moscow's Bolshoi) and collecting them at the box office on the night is just as easy as doing the same in London's West End. The Mariinsky Theatre is looking very tired but renovations are planned once the New Mariinsky Theatre is completed in 2013. We had the pleasure of seeing a beautiful and technically brilliant production of Swan Lake. The set was light touch which was a nice change to the Royal Ballet and enabled the audience to focus on the dancers. The third act had the finest dancing we've ever seen in Swan Lake, hands down. Tips for attending: - Dress code isn't as formal as it used to be. Similar to London, there's a range from evening dress to jeans. - Don't expect to find a full Mariinsky Shop to buy suvinors on the evening of performances. Apparently there is one, but it closes well before the performance starts (missed opportunity Mariinsky!). - the Theatre is a bit of a distance from the tourist centre. You can catch a bus from Nevsky Prospect but if it's winter, a taxi is worth it. Locals told us that the current Conductor favours Opera and that the ballet has taken a backseat. I hope Mariinsky's management come to their senses - while improving the company's opera is a worthy ambition, lessening their commitment to ballet in anyway would be a mistake. Their reputation as one of the world's greatest ballet companies is a great source of pride and tourism for the city. It'd be a shame to the City and dance to see that lapse.

Very ornate. We saw Swan Lake Ballet. On entering the theatre was a stunning sight and the ballet most enjoyable, however the seats were very hard and uncomfortable after a while and the theatre became very hot. Take a bottle of water with you as the bar was far too busy and queues to long to wait for a drink. Many people brought picnics/sandwiches with them which seemed to be allowed

Exceptional ballet but theatre a little tired looking. We visited the Marinsky Theatre and the ballet was excellent but we found the theatre a little disappointing as it is rather tired looking. The Russians often take small children to evening performances which, on the one hand, is great but can be irritating if you are sittling next to a small child who may be restless and easily distracted.

beatiful little theatre. We saw swan lake at the Marinsky and it was a delight.The entrance to the Marinsky is a little hard to find ( it's via a small door to the RIGHT of the canal as you face the building)

Absolutely lovely. Very beautiful old theater. Unlike at the Bolshoi, we had front row seats in the box with a good view of the stage. While not an opera affeciado, the Marinsky did something that "made" the evening a memorable experience. Above the stage, high enough to not be distracting, but easy to see, were the words in ENGLISH. We saw Tschowsky's "Queen of Spade" and had no previous understanding of it. But the English words made it easy to follow. I am still not a fan of opera, but the experience was wonderful and worth the price

Watch the drinks. Visit the ballet was wonderful! I can;t say I was really looking forward to it but it really was a spectacle. One incident was just difficult to handle as a Scotsman. We had a glass of sparkling wine and some red caviar bites before going in. At first break, we were too slow out and queue too long so we just went back to our seats. At final interval I rushed out and joined the queue. As I got to the front, I could only see an open bottle of French champagne. I asked for two champagnes and was asked for 2,400 Roubles (nearly £50)! I nearly choked but with impatient crowd behind, we scraped up the money and retired to lick our wounds.It didn't spoil the rest of the evening,,,,, but came close!

What a great experience!. Mariinsky Theatre has a storied history. Founded in the mid-19th century. But don't just look at the theatre - buy tickets and experience the opera or ballet in St. Petersburg! One tip - when selecting your seats online (definitely do it before you leave home), try to pick seats in the first row of each section. It will make it easier to see.

Went to see a show. Unfortunately for us, the Opera we saw (Dead Souls) wasn't the best. The seats were quite uncomfortable and expensive (suspect it was because we were not Russian). I think if you are not that into Opera, just going into the foyer for a nosey would do. A pretty theatre though.

Mariinsky in need of facelift. A once gorgeous theatre with an international reputation for excellence failed to deliver. Having sat through three different operas in the same week, there was a sad lack of quality singing, they all needed acting lessons and the sets were dull in all productions. The redeeming feature was the wonderful orchestra - around 100 musicians, one of the largest assembled in an orchestra pit. They were superb. The whole building is in need of a facelift which I believe is on the cards.

The Kirov were perfect. They make our ballet dancers look like clodhoppers. The foyer is faded and dirty, but once through the gates the reception rooms (of which there are many) are small and intimate, and beautifully presented. The auditorium is rococo and amazing, and the ballet was just fantastic.

Great theatre - worth a trip even though it costs. What a spectacular building! You should go if you can afford it. I would not recommend buying tickets at the ticket office in the yellow building on Nevsky - unless you can speak Russian. The office is tiny and they are closed the weirdest times (probably for coffee breaks and lunch). One woman sells tickets and one woman opens the door and only lets in five People at a time. Not very efficient and not very service-friendly. But this is the Russian experience. They do not speak English in the office and it doesn't seem like they will learn anytime soon. ;)You can buy tickets online, which you probably should do if you don't speak Russian.The Mariinsky is great. From the Nevsky Prospect (at around number 20 by American fast food place "Subway") you can take the bus to the Mariinsky. Take bus 3, 27 or 22. You can buy tickets on board the bus by a person wearing a neon coloured vest. Get off after about 5 stops (just ask someone on the bus, most of the people are probably going to the same show as you). The bus stopped just outside the theatre.There is a cloak room - some staff will tell you which entrance and cloack room according to your ticket. You can buy wine, beer, soft drinks and small sandwiches and pastries before the show starts. You can't bring the drinks in with you, so be sure to have enough time.We saw Don Quiote with Russian subtitles. I think if they are singing in Russian you get English subtitles. We just bought a programme with the English description. There is free wifi (at least on my Windows Phone there war)- it's called MT (for Mariinsky theatre). Just log on - no code.

Such a display of dance it takes your breath away. We saw Nutcracker which was first performed at this theatre. The scenery is brilliant, the music a delight but it was the dance we came for and we were not disappointed. So much and such brilliance with large school of dancers all of the highest standard. The theatre is well geared for numbers with plenty of cloakrooms and bars and the seats are proper seats. The decoration in the theatre is splendid but the dance, the dance.....
Beautiful, like no other ballet company. The theatre, the costumes and of course the dancers! This is one spectacular troupe and it shows! Make reservations in advance

Over rated. By far this Opera/Ballet theater is over rated. The acoustics are no better than Heinz Hall or the Vienna Opera House just to name a few. I did not find the building to be that interesting either.What was interesting is that they produce their programs in the original language, have subtitles in Russian: and have programs which can be purchased, in both Russian and English (I think maybe French too). I wish the street and Metro signs in Moscow would have been.

Wonderful. I booked our tickets on line and the staff were extremely helpful in chosing the best seats available for my budget. We had a box 19 on the baignoire. I was worried that it would be uncomfortable seeing the ballet, which was absolutely beautiful, from the side but it wasn't a problem. There were 3 seats at the front, 3 behind and a couple of raised chairs at the back. The front seats were fine, one of my friends was behind us and saw the ballet ok.In fact it felt quite special being in a box. The theatre is beautiful. Worth a visit if you get the opportunity.
WOW. Fortunate to see the opera. It is beautiful. Absolutely beautiful. Spend a night or do the day tour! Nothing like it .

A must if you are into the arts. We booked in advance online a few days before. The prices are pretty expensive and I think partly foreigners get charged more. The theatre inside is beautiful and a must see. We saw a very good ballet and it was very easy to follow thankfully. Really interesting to see how important ballet is for the Russians.

Beautiful theater.. Attended the ballet at the theater which was beautiful and thought the performance was a better quality than the Bolshoi or anything in the states. Also went to the concert hall and thought it was a great space.

Looks Great Choose Seats Carefully. We got out tickets directly through the Mariinsky Theatre website (somewhat hard to figure out how to operate). So we could choose our seats and make sure they were in the center area.We saw Swan Lake with one of their stars, Galina Ulanova and the theatre was packed. Young Russians stood at the back or even on the stairs through the whole performance.For the ballet, we were in the first row of the second balcony from the top. First row was fine-no one blocking your view. The second night we went to an opera and had seats in the second row in the next balcony down. The second row is right behind the first row, no step up. As a short woman, I would have been infuriated to be there for ballet ; of course in ballet you want to see the feet. For opera it was OK though it was stuffy.The theatre itself (which I think they are planning to redo but I do not know the details) has all the gilt and velvet you would expect, as well as ceilings with the ornate moulding no one could afford to pay for nowadays.The evil sorcerer was excellent, very powerful. Ulanova had the strong technique you associate with Russian ballet but not a strong dramatic ability. The corps looked stunning in the third act with their beautiful black and white costumes, but were not perfectly synchronized. But it was thrilling to be in the Mariinsky Theatre in St. Petersburg seeing the Mariinsky Ballet doing Swan Lake. How much more quintessentially Russian can you get. When we got out at 11 pm there was still light in the sky.

The woven texture of arts and politics. Our trip was designed to introduce my16 year old grandaughter to the role of performing and fine arts from the Romanovs and evolving and dissolving governments through the 20th century. Visit exhibits in some of the ballerina apartments and attend an opera.
Mariinsky Magic. Lovely theatre. We were very lucky to have seen the ballet Spartacus - wonderful dancing. Well worth the trek to get there in the snow and cold.

Spartacus Ballet. On Saturday December 9, 2012, I found a ticket for 100 euros at the last moment, a good seat wit a very good view on the stage. I liked The colourful scenes, the full house, the most interesting publikum.
I didn't like the music, I feel the acustic was not ideal, too loud and vibrations on the walls and seats.

Very good, ballet was impressive as was the Theatre.. Obviously Kirov Ballet is top notch. Hard to argue whats better or worse, likely depends on the performance that night and your liking of the show, but its certainty top 10 in the world. The Mariinsky theater is also quite impressive and would be worth a quick tour even if you weren't seeing a show. There are some bad seats in the theater, but ours were great and it looked like anything that wasn't at a severe angle would be decent. I would also avoid the back part of the bottom floor area.

The highlight of my visit to Russia. I saw La Bayadere and Don Quixote danced by the world famous Mariinsky ballet. The standard of dance was extremly high as you would expect. The interior of the theatre is very old but this adds to the charm. Took some amazing photographs of the exterior. Highly recommended !

Super!. I have always wanted to attend ballet in Russia and this was my first experience - truly spectacular. It was not that expensive either. I book online via their official website then printed off the reference and collected my tickets before the show on the night. Super Excellent Service, and heres a tip - if you hire the opera glasses then you can skip to the top of the que for the cloak room!

Beautiful!. I have been here twice in the last week due to visiting relatives, once for a ballet (Romeo and Juliet) and once for a play (My Fair Lady) and it is without a doubt a beautiful theatre, with a very high level of talent on its stage and in its orchestra pit - however, I have not yet visited a theatre in St Petersburg that has disappointed, and I have been here for nearly 3 months and been to my fair share of ballets and plays! The Mariinsky does very good student discounts for certain seats, and in my opinion, the seats right at the top are the best bet - I paid a fraction of the price to sit there compared to the price for a seat along one of the sides, and the view was MUCH better!

We saw Firebird, great experience. We booked our seats on-line in a box and our Russian in-laws booked the same box. very easy to do. The ballet was very good but the experience was a not to be missed experience.Half time having blini and Caviar was great Russian Champagne left me cold.Get their early as not an easy entrance.

Not to be missed. We ordered our tickets online and had them sent to our hotel for our arrival. This service is free. The ballet was a midsummer nights dream. I would say expensive at £116 in comparison to our ballet but good seats on the second tear next to the Tzar box. The building is beautiful and the stage curtain is amazing. Staff are helpful and always try to accomodate our lack of Russian language. If visiting St Petersburg this theatre is well worth seeing. It is full of interesting history.
a place where the magic happens .... Apart from the fact that the inside of the building is a true beauty, the performances on stage are world-class. A must during your stay in Peter!

Fabulous ballet in a beautiful setting. We had booked tickets on line before we went (you can print your tickets at home) and had really good seats. Worked out at about £80 each which is a bargain compared to London!Huge cast (Romeo and Juliet) and the theatre itself is a work of art.
we loved it. Get the tickets online ,incredible orchestra,great staging,take a taxi to your hotel-tickets cheeper online than onsite about 30%

World Class Performance. We watched 'Midsummer Night's Dream' by Kirov Ballet. It was a world class performance that took my breath away.We got the seats on the second row of a box on the 1st circle which was a totally bad idea. Our view was obstructed by the audiences in front of us because the seats on the second row were not elevated. I ended up standing up most of the time during the performance.

Old and new. The Mariinsky Theatre is an old world venue with a beautiful interior however the seating on old wooden chairs leaves much to be desired, we were seated in a box on the second balcony of seven overlooking the stalls where the seats were all chairs.The production was world class and well worth the visit, we booked on line and the system worked for both the Theatre and the concert hall, what did spoil the visit was the number of mobile phones videoing the performance ( I counted 30) at the end and was blinded by a battery of cameras by visiting business men sitting in front.The concert hall be careful where you book i s new and we saw two different shows one was full and the other empty , the accoustics incredible but the seating terrible uncomfortable and many seats lack a good view , the performances were in the round and incredible, beware of lack of toilets for men and women

Very good but..... Super performance but we were very disappointed that the ballet wasn't at the Mariinsky Theatre but at the Mariinsky concert hall (5 min walk away). We didn't know this until we arrived and there was no explanation where to go - just a man pointing. We don't speak Russian so were clueless! In the end we followed a lady, very elegantly dressed who looked like she might attend and fortunately she did and we sat down with a minute to spare - moral of the story - check which venue your ticket is for!!

Highlight of our Trip to St Petersburg. Before I talk about our experiences a word of advise - do book ahead via the internet if you want to obtain good seats as some shows are fully booked well in advance. Yes, you will pay more than the locals do, but it is still good value compared to other European cities.The Mariinsky is the home of the Kirov ballet and has been made famous in the past by Nureyev & Baryshnikov. We were fortunate enough to have good seats for the opening night of Swan Lake. The production and performers were the best we have ever seen and it made for a special evening.The building itself from the outside is not that special, on the inside, it is quite small which makes for an intimate atmosphere. Go early if you can as the theatre is fun to explore and also has some nice places to eat. I highly recommend going to the Mariinsky even if your not an opera or ballet fan you will find it rewarding.

A step back in history at 1/2 the price of NY, London, or Paris. I am a 7 year resident of the city.... The theater is like stepping back in time to that of the royalty of Europe. It is opulent and full of tradition. Just as in the "Old Days" during intermission people exit the theater into the halls and promenade, chat and partake of the Russian treats available at the kiosks. Some of the most wonderful concerts I have ever attended were here.
Stunning theatre. We didn't book until late so we were seated at the very top of the buidling,people in front blocked our view but it was still magical to see the Kirov ballet performing Giselle!

parfait for opera lovers. If you truly enjoy opera you will be delighted! Marinski theater is on a level of La Scala or Opéra de Paris. Wagner performances are excellent! Also, one should see Turandot.

Historic Value. A must see for the theatre's historic value and the excellence of the dancers (though the English National Ballet seem better coordinated). Beautiful exterior and interior however visibility of the stage can be somewhat impaired if you are unfortunate enough to have tall people seated in front of you - the incline of the seating should be steeper.

A worthwhile experience but not necessarily world class opera. We are opera buffs so of course planned our trip to st Petersburg around two trips to the opera. I'm glad we went twice as it showed how variable the performances can be. The first opera, Love for 3 Oranges, was an outstanding production with great performances from the orchestra and the chorus but variable and some surprisingly weak performances from the soloists. We'd picked the second opera, Pelleas et Melisande, because Gergiev was conducting, per the website. Gergiev was a no show. I'm used to prima Donna soloists being no shows but this was our first experience of a conductor no show. However the orchestra was again excellent and this time the soloists were also excellent and their French diction was better than some French singers we've heard. However the production was weak. The opera house itself is delightful and the local audience significantly younger and more enthusiastic than you'd see at a major opera house in the west. The website is easy to use - no need to go via a third party to get your tickets. The loos are in short supply with long queues so plan ahead. Interval drinks are also a challenge as there is one lady serving everybody in the stalls and first balcony.

Opera in New Concert Hall is Great. I attended the Marriage of Figaro in the Concert Hall of Mariinsky and was blown away. The concert hall was finished in 200 and is very modern. The acoustics are unbelievable! The stage is somewhat surrounded by audience. The seating is very comfortable. The staging of the opera was the best I have ever seen. Being a surrounded stage, it had to be innovative and it was. The singers were superlative. Karina Chepernova, who sang Susanna, was unbelievable!!!!

Not to be missed for ballet fans. My wife and I saw Romeo & Juliet. Very large and skilled cast. Very dramatic performance. If you just want to look at the ceiling, you can admire the splendid chandelier! It was a challenge to find the toilets during the intervals...!

Great theatre, ho-hum show. The Mariinsky Theatre itself is wonderful: beautiful and surprisingly intimate for a world-renowned venue.Unfortunately, the show we chose--Prokofiev's The Love For 3 Oranges--was lacklustre. The orchestra and singers were all fine; but the direction and production values were dull and tired. On the plus side, while English programs were not available, surtitles were rendered in English. Unfortunately, due to a technical staging gaffe, the surtitles during the second act were obscured by drapery.

So we visit St Petersburg to watch Shakespeare !!. So we visited the great Marinsky...where ballet is supposed to have started, and watched 'Midsummer Nights Dream'. Kirov ballet troop perfomed very well and what a Fabulous theatre. Not a huge theatre, but lots of atmosphere and you can easily imagine life back in the 1900's when this was high Russian society!We registered with Marinsky website and waited for our tickets to become available online. Good service, takes a bit of navigating...lots of security and you need you credit card details which if not entered quickly will time out and you have to start again...very frustrating! Tickets reasonable...we paid around £ 220 for two seats about six rows back in the stalls. Excellent!The theatre is surrounded by several good restaurants and we reserved our table before the show....a must as the restaurants fill quickly after the show and we watched several couples get turned away.Overall a great experience, well worth the money and a great nights entertainment with quality ballet.

Unforgettable ballet dance. We were watching swan lake. We didn't get the most expensive seat and actually we were quite far away from the stage and we were at the balcony. However, the theater was not huge so you pretty much could see anywhere you sit. The theater was beautiful. The show was great! You should always try to get a ticket for the show even though it was the cheapest one as it is worth seeing.

Contempory concert hall. Per their website, this is supposedly one of the best concert halls in Europe, from an acoustic point of view at least. If you like music, it's worth visiting and the acoustics are good but not as good as I'd expected. But quite a contrast to the marinski opera in all sorts of ways. Comfortable seats, great sight lines, lots of foyer space, an ability to get interval drinks without queuing, ushers who speak English, programmes in English. Indeed you might be in western Europe or the US except that the evening we were there there were lots of children and people under the age of 30 for classical music, which was great. One of the pieces we heard was a piano concerto. The orchestra was excellent but the piano sounded odd and rather tinny. It is a Steinway. The pianist was excellent. I blame the acoustics and perhaps our seats, which were near the front. Another time I'd try much further back.

Fabulous - even for a non ballet fan. Its hard to imagine coming to this part of the world and not going to the ballet. The Kirov was an excellent choice.The theatre itself is majestic and full of character, the performance creative and slick.It was a tad expensive, but hey, you make your choices and you live with them.

Could not see the stage. We purchased tickets to Wagner opera through the internet from the Opera and Ballet site. We paid relatively high prices (300% more than locals) and got seats on a position from which we could hardly see the stage. Better to buy directly from the Mariinsky site and to make sure that tickets seats are in the center and in first row of the balconies.

It's a must for music lovers. I'm not a lover of the building's green paint, but other than that, it's rich with history. Think of the amazing talent that has performed here, you have to go. We saw Valerie Gergiev conduct The Ring Cycle. We were sitting no more than 30 feet from him; it was amazing to watch him work. The staging was minimal, yet very effective.

Beautiful Ballet. Never thought I would get my husband to sit through a ballet, but he did and thoroughly enjoyed it as well. Very professionally done and the small theater provided an up close and personal experience.
Marinsky Theatre. Unforgettable have not seen anything like it. A must see in St Petersburg. A well worth visit with plent of photos
A must-see. The ballet is wonderfully traditional, down to the use of armchairs in the auditorium. The auditorium is spectacular in itself, but this is nothing compared to the quality of the ballet.
Always the best. I especially recommend the operas. Although the ballet speaks for itself. My favorite opera is Turandot.

A dream come true for any fan or student of classical dance.. The Marinsky Theater, The Kirov Ballet...such history!!A beautiful, very old, and slightly worn down venue for seeing one of the best and most famous ballet companies in the world.This is the equilivelent of seeiing Perlman play at Carnegie Hall, or watching Olivier act atvthe Old Globe. Fantastic!The romantic period, lush style, red velvet drapes, individual gilt painted high back chairs in the "Czar's Box", the fact that Pavlova, Nuriev, Najinsky, Barishnakov all started dancing in this theater just gives a dance fan goose bumps while watching the latest crop of perfect dancers tour jette' across the stage.

Not sure what the fuss is about. I'm not sure that Russian ballet is still the world standard-bearer when it comes to performances - I for one, have seen more inspiring performances in the United States. Also, tends to turn into an elbow-shoving contest on the way out which detracts from the experience

Beautiful ballet and theatre. We went to see Swan Lake and it was absolutely beautiful. We were on a cruise and our group got to meet the main dancers after the show which made the evening even more special. Theatre is stunning although it was very hot inside, there is no air conditioning and the seats are cramped but it was incredible anyway. Highly recommend this as the dancers are superb and the orchestra excellent too.
Swan Lake. .. at the Mariinsky Theatre - can it get better? The theatre itself is a work of art, as are many of the buildings in St Petersburg. The ballet company was superb!

Highly recommended. We have been to Giselle ballet on 29 June 2012, the ballet was very nice, seats were excellent (row 10, central stalls). The theater is much smaller comparing to Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, but it is intimate and nice, even if it looks a little older, but more authentic. I liked it very much.

The ballets are high end . The building not bad either. Marinsky is not the architectoral miracle of Bolshoi of Moscow , but surpases all in the etheral quality of the ballet. Dont go there for the building . Go0 for a ballet . Does not matter which one. Any!! It is simply divine.

Such fun!. Really a good taste of Russian folk dance and music with laughs and liveliness...Like the previous reviews I read, don't expect a sumptuous buffet dinner - it's a snack and a quick vodka or champagne - plus tables selling various goods during the interval....

If you love ballet, you'll love this theatre!. Wonderful performances by world class dancers. The bonus for me is that ballet performances where I live are usually quite pricey (for my student budget anyway) and I was able to attend several performances for less than what I would have paid for one back home. The building itself is pretty too! There is a lot of intricate woodwork and detailing to look at while you wait for the performances to begin.

Requires a lot of patience. I went to a performance that was supposed to contain 3 short ballets performed over a total of about 45 minutes (according to their website). I was happy to find a performance this short since I was supposed to be on a very early flight out of the city the next morning. The first act was beautifully performed; everything positive that I'd heard about the theater proved to be true (absolutely stunning building that alone is worth the price of admission, amazingly talented performers). Then nothing happened -- for an hour, everyone just sat there waiting for something to happen. After about 45 minutes the audience started clapping / chanting, trying to persuade the performers to continue. I unfortunately had to leave an hour after the first act to catch my aforementioned flight, but as I left there was still nothing going on in the theater. No explanation or announcement was made of any kind. I mentioned what happened to my taxi driver and he basically said that he was sorry that had happened and that it is very typical of performances there. So the bottom line is that it's worth going, but leave yourself FAR more time than is stated on the website if you want to see an entire performance.I was mostly after seeing the building and getting a taste for the ballet (I'm pretty far from a performing arts aficionado). So I got pretty much all I wanted from the performance, but have to knock it back to 2 stars since taking an hour off in the middle of a 45 minute performance without any explanation is bad form.
NIce. I have been visiting there much earlier than Aug 2011. It is a real institution!In case You want to enjoy the very best culture in this town, so this is a very good choice.
A must for ballet lovers. A great theatre and the standard of the Ballet is world class. Tickets are expensive.Best to buy on the internet

Wonderful experience in historical theater. This was the highlight of my trip to Russia and I am not normally a ballet fan! We saw a Stravinsky "double header" during White Nights, and that in itself is rare. Rite of Spring and Firebird. My husband, an orchestral musician, put this on our agenda, mainly so he could hear the orchestra with the ballet. He had never played those pieces with a live ballet, so this gave him a new perspective. We got tickets online prior to our trip. We used the Mariinsky's webiste. I think that some English language sites out there greatly inflate the prices, so just stick with the theater's ticketing site. We picked up our tickets at Will Call without waiting in a long line. Dress: I had read that it is very dressy, but I did not find this to be the case. Dressy casual will work. I had a black travel dress and a black wrap and my husband wore a dress shirt and slacks and we were perfectly dressed. The theater is beautiful. I liked sitting there thinking of all of the famous dancers who have been behind that curtain. We were in the lower balcony, first row. There are individual seats, but they are rather narrow. Also, we were seated close to a "peak"- it was like a roof over the entrance to the level below. Hard to describe, but the seats in front of that obstruction would have had limited views. The snack bar on the box seat level has enormously expensive champagne, so be cautioned. We observed some people walk away from their order because they had hoped to pay with credit card, but it was roubles only. The intermission was very long, based on my experience, so there was plenty of time for getting a bite to eat or visiting the WC.

White Nights festival. Attended an opera during the White Nights festival. The theatre is beautiful and I doubt there are more than a few "bad" seats. The production of Tosca that we saw was professional and beautifully staged. We easily acquired our tickets online beforehand and picked them up 30 minutes before the performance.

A must. Wonderful place, a must for ballet and opera fans. Tickets bought from russian internet sites are several times cheaper than those from foreign sites! A little luck is necessary to find the desk where to buy a glass of chapmpagne in the break.
Marinsky Theatre. Beautiful inside, Ballet wonderfully graceful, excellent performance. Priced resonably well. Can go dressy casual. Enjoyed very much

No better place to watch ballets in their birthplace. Led by great Valery Gergiev the company stages classical ballets and operas in the perfect original Grand Russian style. Preserving the great tradition of past generations.Get yourself a ticket before you come to the city. Warmly recommended anyone will enjoy.Taker your time to visit the cafe and the huge lobby on the second floor. And please do not take photographs with flash !!!
Must watch a ballet!!!. We went to see a ballet!! it was great!!! the teather is beautiful, but the performance was excellent too!!

Like Magic. Our hotel helped us get tickets and we were very happy we paid the money. Like going to Broadway for a show in New York, the ballet in Russia is a must for culture oriented tourists. This is the place, it is like Magic with it's rich history, lovely architecture and premier performances. Just do it.
been there before. One of the best theaters on this planet, and of course St Petersburg school of Ballet IS the BEST!!!

Stellar Performance. Booking tickets before the trip on line got us into a performance that was sold out by the time we arrived in town. Top balcony seats are on padded benches with no space between people, but we were in the front row of that balcony and had no problem seeing everything. We were a bit squished for space but it was worth it to see such a top level performance. (Kirov Ballet)
Wonderful, ballet, concerts and opera. What a wealth of culture, we went to several performances in this very magnificent theater.

First ballet and hardly slept. Okay, so I am not a fan of ballet. However, we saw Stravinski's Firebird. We had great seats (for over $100 each). I can't say that I understood it, but it was interesting and the prima ballerina had great talent. However, the male lead didn't dance at all. I was quite surprised by this considering the famous male stars that have come out of this theatre. This theatre was quite stunning from the inside. They are building a new theatre that is suppose to be state of the art when it is completed.

Grande Theatre. You can identify this theater by its mint green colour. As you walk inside the small hallways are not very impressive and I started to wonder about the condition of the theater. Walking into the main theater my fears were cast off and you see the beautiful fresco, sculptures, and ornate trimming to make a very wondrous space.The chairs have some room between them and are not jammed together to maximize seating. As I looked around I saw that most of the seats and boxes had clear views. I saw a ballet of Le Corsaires. The performance was not highly technical but very fulfilling with a decent story line and good dancing. With a new ballet every night I assume that these are many different companies or mostly understudy. It would be impossible to know a different ballet every night for the whole White Night season. As others have stated there are many people here from cruise ships and they will be using their flash photography even though they are 20 meters from the stage in a dimly lit room. Expect to have the audience gradually get bolder as the performance progresses and the rate of flashes increase.There are small concessionary booths that serve some alcohol and no beer. There are some pastries and quick snacks too. There is a coat check and the ticket booth was organized.I highly suggest buying the tickets online to avoid standing in long lines. The tickets during White Nights will sell out fast as the cruise ships dock.
Mariinsky Theatre. Was there to see Swan Lake during Stars of the White Night, it was amazing (and I don't even like ballet)

Excellent. The ballet was wonderful, the opera slightly less so. The place has no air conditioning (or it feels it hasn't anyway) and if it is a hot day it is very, VERY hot, which detracts from the experience. Apart from that, the calibre of the dancers is absolutely first-class and this covers ALL the dancers, not just the main ones.

A Rare Treat, despite savages in the audience. We attended a performance of Swan Lake during the White Nights Festival and it was a top experience. Completely worth itHuge negative: Despite the announcement and contrary to every possible rule of manners, boorish, shame-free audience members clicked their flash cameras during every single iconic moment of the ballet. It was sickening. Their discourtesy was matched only by their stupidity in using their flashes. Did any of them actually think their cell phone/digital camera illumination was enough to light the auditorium. What rude idiots.But, go. Book you tickets online as far in advance as possible.The restrooms are stuck by the bar on the second level, so be fleet of foot at intermission to minimize your wait in line if you're a woman.

Stupendous. We went to see Le Parc at the Mariinsky Theatre. Ballet was amazing. The theatre is so beautiful, never could imagine a place so spectacular. I was overwhelmed with it's beauty. Very functional and I am sure every seat is a good seat.
A night not to be believed. For a balletomane this was heaven. It's interesting that ballet is for everyone in russia. Intermission is a time to eat, chat and be fully immersed in the art of dance

amazing. Sat in the 3rd balcony and could still see everthing very well. Not the best behaviour going on up there, though. The Kirov ballet company are amazing. The corps is out of this world. A must for ballet lovers
The best ballet in whole world. You just have to book tickets ion advance via travel agency or their website http://www.mariinsky.ru/en/

How to Get There. If you would like get to the Theater by public transportation, take a metro to Sennaya Plsch´had. (27 R a ride). Exiting at the square look for the canal (Griboedova) that runs behing one side of the square. Parked there you will find one or two mini buses. Ask the driver if they go to the Mariinsky, just say Maiinskiy. The driver He wil reply "Da" or "Niet". No problem if one doesn´t go another that does will arrive soon. It seems to me that these mini buses departs when full and another comes after a few minutes. They charge 30R and in 10 minutes you will be dropped just in front of the theater. Total cost of the ride US$2.00

Ballet at its best. We saw Swan Lake here and it was wonderful. Make certain you purchase your tickets online early as they sell out fast. The theatre is much smaller than we had expected, but just stunning. We had tickets to the fourth row from front and viewing was slightly difficult for my young son as seats only tier slights. Best location we believe would be on the first or second level front row. Even if you can not get good seats do go as it is a must do experience!

Swan Lake - Nothing else be said!. I used the link above on trip advisor to buy the ticket on Marinsky's website. All the other websites are ticket brokers and much more expensive. If you can't get at ticket on the official website then a 3rd party is your only option.I registered on the website and bought a box ticket on the 1st floor and it was an excellent view, I think $172. Remember you must bring the e-mailed copy of the order certificate with the code and a picture ID to collect the ticket at Will Call. The best of the best.... If you are at all interested in the world of classical dance or opera, Mariinsky Theater is THE place to experience it. The theater is as elegant and ornate as its reputation suggests, and the greatest dancers and singers have graced its historic stage. Every time I go, I know it is going to be a world class cultural event. It is unfortunate that the ballet company's season covers all year except when so many visitors would enjoy attending. August into early September is their off season. When it starts up again in September, its is a good reason to postpone a vacation to St Petersburg until fall when the city's full 11 month cultural year begins again. It is a nice to come to the city because hotels are cheaper, there are fewer lines in museums and the pace is more relaxed all over the city.

For me it was better under communism 26 years ago.. A return after 26 years to the city, now St Petersburg and again for the White Nights' Festival in June. Seats are still hard and close together, but they no longer cost a handful of rubles or the equivalent of £3-4. So they cost much the same as the medium price range at the Royal Opera House in London. Black caviar at about £1-2 per large dollop has gone to be replaced with a teaspoonful of red salmon caviar on a tiny blini. One of those and two glasses of so-called champagne (we made the mistake of not asking for "champnasky", the Russian sparkling wine and were given a similar tasting product from an open bottle of Moet & Chandon) and no change from £40! So be careful what you ask for at the small kiosks that pass as bars.And theatre goers no longer parade slowly anti-clockwise around the grand salon behind the former imperial box at the interval which is a shame, but we all move with the times.The two ballet performances were superb: imagine 32 ballerinas all on pointe in white and in perfect synch. And all the principal dancers were magnificent.The two operas were disappointingly average. Of the 4 performances we saw only one started and even finished on time with another one over-running by 45 mins to finish just before midnight., but at least it was still daylight outside.Russians seem to expect this and, to encourage late conductors and dawdling orchestra members to take their places, applaud the near empty pit as they would on the entry of the conductor. Unlike 26 years ago many of the staff can cope with directing those with at least some English to their boxes or seats, which is necessary as seat numbers are not intuitive and are hidden on seat backs in the gloom. English versions of the programmes are also available, but, of course, "surtitles" are in Russian. Access to seats is still rather last minute.A huge irritation that is the fault of the audience is the flash photography, though banned, throughout the performance. And the blue glow of smart phones and i-Pad type devices among the audience after the house lights are down is intensely distracting and irritating. This is the worst audience behaviour I have experienced.Twenty six years ago, as the Soviet Union was coming to an end though softened by Glastnost and the USSR and much of Europe was anxiously watching the radiation clouds from Chernobyl, a night at the then Kirov to see Tchaikovsky's "Queen of Spades", which is set in imperial St Petersburg, was stunningly presented and performed and sung and the whole event was memorable. The Mariinsky seems to me now to be struggling to set a standard except in its wonderful ballet company and for that alone it is worth a visit - and the interior of the auditorium is magnificent.

A moving experience. Thanks to the long and energetic tenure of the theatre’s incumbent Music Director, Valery Gergiev, international opera lovers have plenty of opportunities to attend performances of the Mariinsky Theatre artistic ensembles on tour around the world. I had already attended performances of this outstanding artistic ensemble in London, Paris and Rome. But this only increased my motivation to attend a performance in their home ground, the Mariinsky Theatre in St. Petersburg.The theatre looks a bit run down and in desperate need of an overhaul – as it was done recently at the Bolshoi in Moscow. But this did not detract anything to the charm of the place.They have an extended repertoire, but I wanted to see a Russian Opera. So I attended a matinée performance of "The Tsar Saltan" by Rimsky Korsakov, staying clear of the billboard of the many scheduled performances of Italian warhorses like Tosca and Traviata – which seemed to me to be routine performances of little artistic value, albeit probably very good for the box office.The Mariinsky Orchestra was conducted by a "maestro sostituto" and there were no international opera stars among the singers. But I enjoyed the consistently high artistic level and the attendance of a young - I would say very young - audience. Very well behaved in spite of the young age!I booked my tickets from the Theatre website, and that worked out very well. All in all, a moving experience, which I am eager to repeat at the next suitable occasion.

Exceeded my expectations! Book now!. However, this play was so magical that nothing could have ruined it.Be aware that you have to buy the tickets well in advance, especially if you're visiting the theatre during a high-season (Christmas, Russian White nights). I bought my tickets online from the official website of the Mariinsky theatre about a month and a half before my visit. There is an English version of the website (mariinsky.ru) where you can easily select the seats of your choice. As soon as you purchase the tickets, you should print your e-ticket (which you will find in your online account ) and get the paper tickets when you are in the city (from one of the two Mariinsky theatres or a ticket booth in Nevsky Prospekt - Gostiny Dvor). It's easy and all the details are written in the email that you receive when you buy the tickets.It's not an exclusive attraction for old people only. It targets easily the general audience. You can check the schedule, listen the music online and select what attracts you most. Book tickets now and enjoy! :-)

World class opera and ballet. The long-standing reputation of the Mariinsky (formerly Kirov) theater is confirmed immediately on a first visit. But here is the most important tip of all: scalper organizations are rampant in St. Petersburg, with prices that are as much as double those of the Mariinsky Theatre itself. A couple of drawbacks but a great evening out.. I went to one ballet and one opera here during my visit to St. Petersburg. The Opera "Atilla" was not one I was familiar with, but I enjoyed it. Atilla the Hun in a hot pink shirt was a bit of a shocker. OK, it was the party scene, but still. Romeo had a "cape" that wrapped around his legs and almost tripped him a couple of times and the girls skirts were far too long. All the costumes looked very cheap. They seem to have spent money on the stage sets though - they were wonderful for both performances. Finally, I booked online months in advance and was horrified when I discovered my seat had an obstructed view. I'm used to theaters that mention this when you book. I could easilly have chosen another seat if they had labelled it as partially obstructed. Fully one third of the stage was missing. To charge full price for a seat where you can only see 2/3 of the performance takes some real cheek. Overall, it was still worth going, but chose your seats wisely.

The trip to and from the theatre, and the long days of summer solstice allowed easy photography from the bus with interesting light effects in the gloaming. The theatre itself has an impressive lobby with sculptures and paintings. Inside the main theatre the seating and adornments to the house were minimal, more like a movie theatre than a grand opera house. The performance we saw was only half full.The ballet itself, Giselle, was performed the the Kirof young company and they did a competent job. Costumes and musical accompaniment was also acceptable if not inspiring. Unintentional humour came from a cheap, purchased program which had some of the most inventive English translations I've ever seen. As a cultural event it was over-priced, but at least you got the sense of what the Russian public consider as high-brow entertainment.

Very Impressive! It's Not Just A Performance, It's An Event To Attend... We went to the ballet Romeo&Juliet of Prokofiev buying two of the last 6 tickets on the day of the performance! We had heard and was advised to buy tickets ahead since most of the performances were selling off, it really was, but we managed to get in :)Inside the theater is amazing! The curtains, the ceiling.. The performance was very good, you understand why Russian ballet is so famous around the world. The people are dressed up and you see the locals also give very much care to this event. For example we saw a 9-10 year old boy dressed in white shirt, tie and blazer jacket, this gave me the impression that locals care much about it, even bringing their kids in proper dresses. Since we bought last minute tickets, and didn't have time to return to our hotel near the airport and dress up, we remained relatively very casual. One of the ladies helping (warning actually :)) people to find their places stopped us while we were climbing to the floor our seats were, and said somethings in Russian. Seeing we stare at her not understanding, she pointed at our clothing and our coats in hand still in Russian and said "you're in Mariiiiinnnnssy Theater!" (behave yourselves! kind of..), I couldn't help smiling and saying "thank you but please don't beat us!" :) When we got out it was 22:30 pm but the sky hadn't gone dark yet because of the white nights :) It's something one's not used to experience after an evening performance.Last words; Do go to Mariinsky Theater and experience the atmosphere as well as the performance.

Superlative Ballet. Organisation & booking so-so.. Best ballet I've ever watched in my life. They brought the nuance of the performance to the fore in a way I've never experienced before. Superlative.Practicalities wise; Irritating that the prices for tourist are higher than Russians. Feels like they are milking the cash-cows. The bar's are small & understaffed. Expect to wait, & perhaps miss out. Could go like a local & (discretely) bring your own! Still, great people watching, & utterly beautiful Theatre.

Watched Swan Lake - Exquisite. Few words needed here I'm afraid. This was one of the finest productions of any sort that we've seen anywhere. The ballet company really was as good as their reputation. We're not sure enough can be said about the quality and experience provided by the Mariinsky Ballet Company. While our tickets were expensive at 5000 Ruble ($175 USD) per ticket, it seems so very well spent on the evening we watched them perform Swan Lake. We recommend trying to secure the Belle Etage, upstairs box seats. They were the perfect level to really get the best of your Mariinsky experience. We are already thinking of another trip to St. Petes, the Mariinsky will be a first on the list of attractions to repeat. We highly recommend trying to watch a production of some sort here, hopefully you can secure ballet tickets.

Fantastic. I would highly recommend going to the Mariinsky! We went to see Giselle (Kirov Ballet) on a Saturday night while we were there and thoroughly enjoyed it. We bought tickets online. They have an English website which is pretty straightforward. Our seats were quite expensive (in the front of a box near the centre in the back) which were excellent! We had no problems getting our tickets, we just brought the e-mail confirming that we had bought the tickets to the box office 2 hours before it started and were handed the tickets. The theatre is beautiful inside. We felt under dressed as most people dress up but there were quite a few tourists in there so we weren't the only ones in jeans and trainers thankfully. The staff were friendly inside too although didn't speak English but that was fine. It was probably one of the most memorable experiences of the trip for all of us.

Do go but don't book online. As we were so keen to visit the ballet whilst on holiday in St Petersburg we booked on line before going and were given a booking ref to collect our tickets. On arrival at the theatre we were told our tickets were for two weeks prior to our visit. The staff were extremely unhelpful in trying to resolve this issue would not check their confirmation emails etc and end result was we had to queue up three times and buy tickets for a second time. On return home website links to the booking will not work so still can't prove that the booking was correct. The ballet (Cinderella) was wonderful as was the theatre so do recommend a visit but either do not book online or make. Absolutely sure you have a print out which shows the date etc of your booking

Ballet at its best !. Just returned from a short trip to St Petersburg to visit my daughter. Whilst there she took us to see Swan Lake at The Mariinsky Theatre. It was a matinee performance (starting at 11.30 a.m.) so I wasn't expecting the best but.......... absolutely stunning. From first seeing the outside of the building, entering the welcoming reception area, finding our seats.... and then... the ballet. Supeeeerb! Ballet at its best. Three hours long and brilliant from start to finish. It's a must see attraction.

More than a theatre. If you will be anywhere near St. Petersburg, Russia, you must visit the Mariinsky Theatre. What a treasure! A beautiful theater that must be seen and experienced. As I'm nearly 6'6" (2 meters) tall, I find the seating to be very comfortable which is a rare occasion for me.Personally I recommend the Kirov Ballet. Of course the sets, lighting and music are awesome. Some of the performers are not simply supreme ballet dancers, they are really olympic quality athletes. The closest man will ever come to flying on his own happens on the stage of the Mariinsky theater. If it's your first visit, be sure to head to the top floor at intermission for champagne, ice cream (my favorite) and other Russian snacks.
